review_body: Beside "hello, your passport please" , the staff doesn't speak english, the room was very small, the breakfast wasn't very good, we usually had to eat somewhere else. We've been in Japan for a week before Tokyo, staying in Kyoto and Osaka, we were used with the size of the rooms and the japanese food for breakfast and we didn't have any problems there. We booked a massage thinking that they must have a kind of spa in house, they didn't mention while booking at the reception that the masseurs will come to the room and give the massage while climbing in your bed. Not to mention the quality of the massage... while a day before we had somewhere else the best massages ever, at the hotel we had the worst! They should fire those masseurs! At 10 PM, instead of feeling relaxed, we were angry that we couldn't communicate with the masseurs and later with no one at the reception when we asked for new bedsheets because the masseurs not only the put their feet in the bed were we put our faces, but they threw the pillows on the floor. Horrible experience!

The good: clean, comfortable and quiet in an otherwise busy neighbourhood. Easy access to mini supermarkets' combinis and the metro/JR lines. Easy walk to Hammamatsucho to get the monorail to Haneda; and a short jaunt to Shimbashi for late night eats. Ginza is also walkable.We liked the Ippudo along the next street :-)The bad: Inflexibility of staff. We were staying 6 nights. I cannot believe that it was impossible to let us use the bathroom the morning of our arrival after a red-eye flight. Shame.

Japanese like their heating, and by default the rooms are far too warm for us. We turn off the heater and use the aircon to lower the room temperature to around 20 degrees for a good sleep.But in this particular hotel you can only use the heater in wintertime. You can turn off the heater but the aircon is not available during winter. The window can be opened to cool down the room but it only opens a little, and does not let much air in, and there is too much outside traffic noise to sleep. So the room is either too warm or too noisy for a good sleep.Apart from the room temperature the hotel is excellent. The service is outstanding, the room is spotlessly clean, the location very convenient, especially for Haneda Airport and there are plenty of dining options in the area. I would stay again, but perhaps phone ahead to ask them to turn off the room heating before I arrive.

Stayed here because during the weekend its so expensive everywhere else because of the world cup rugby. Supposed to stay 2 nights because of the typhoon Hagibis my flight was cancelled so only got to stay for a short one night only. Reception is very nice and can speak english. Check in process and checkout was every fast and efficient. Location is in a quiet area but if your room facing the rail track it can be quite noisy. The subway is walking within 10-15 mins either way shiodome or hammamatsucho station if you dont mind. The room itself is just decent enough for japanese hotel ard 18-20m. Not big nor too small for japanese std. Just recently renovated so its not weary. Got nice public bath at top floor which is nice if you like onsen. Overall experience here was a nice stopover just wish my room is not facing rail track coz i am a light sleeper got awake easily. Train only stop from 1 am to 5 am i think.

This is an excellent hotel - clean, friendly, good value and easy access from Haneda International Airport.We are staying here two more times during our stay in Japan.Good access to other transport systems

Service is far better than other hotels around. Has Japanese style large public bath for relaxing. However, if you need the Internet for your business, I think you would better avoid this hotel. This is the long-lasting issue of this hotel. The speed of the Internet is far too low to be considered as useful. You will have lots of trouble downloading files, browse the Internet, impossible to have tele/video conference.

A warm welcome, polite and friendly. Very clean.Decent-sized room (at least for me) with a view, not a wall opposite.Nice location, easily walking distance to Shiodome and Shimbashi.Convenience store very near the entrance. Hence 'convenience'....

The hotel is ok, not too big, not too small. What we really liked was the location as it was more in an office area, which meant it was very quiet and chilled at night. We really appreciated this after coming back from the really busy and crazy areas of Tokyo. Lots of stations close by and loads of restaurants in the area. The hotel has a great supermarket in front which came in very handy.

We arrived drenched and the reception staff offered towels. There is additional per hour rate for early check-in. Otherwise, wait till 3pm. The surrounding of this hotel is quiet, good for walks. Rooms and linen were clean. In our 4 days stay, before moving into another hotel, I noticed the reception staff were often stressed.

Close to hamari ryu gardens and tokyo tower and hamamatsucho station of the yamanote line.Modern and comfortable but a bit expensive (specially breakfast)Try to get one of las floor rooms. Impressive views tokyo night.

It is a good 8-10mins walk from Shiodome train station. Room is a bit dated and requires maintenance. Stay away from the fabric sofa, it is not clean. I'm sensitive to dirty fabric sofa and i got rashes after the first night stay. The rash heal after i checked out.

I was happy to discover that the hotel is well located, within 7 minutes of 3 different train lines. Our room was clean & in good condition. The bathroom could be newer but again it was clean. Front desk staff don’t really speak English but I guess that’s Tokyo.

The room was comfortable, and the bathroom was a reasonable size for Japan, as I have been to hotels with very tiny ones. It is well located close to JR and Metro stations, with many restaurants nearby. There is also a small supermarket and several convenience stores (one right next door). The hotel staff were also super friendly and helpful. However, there is no gym in the hotel. We did not try the public bath, so I cannot comment on that.

Good size room for a family of four. Comfortable beds. I particularly love the complimentary coffee. It tastes so good. We stayed during winter. Convenience store, where you can buy cheap, delicious microwaveable meal, is a few steps away. My kids love the fresh milk in Japan. Staff speaks english well. They will look after your luggages if you arrive before check in time.

We stayed here recently for 2 nights. The rooms are a good size for Tokyo and quite comfortable. The staff are amazing! They are very helpful and polite! The public bath on the 13th floor was smallish but great. Didn’t eat there. There are plenty of great eating places within walking distance and several little supermarkets. The hotel is a little old but very clean and in a great location. To and from Hamamatsucho is the best. About 5 minutes walk away. Thoroughly recommend this place and am returning in a few weeks.

The hotel is reasonably priced, clean and conveniently located..close to Hamamatsucho train station (about 6-7 mins walk) that connects you to any where you want to go; there are plenty of eateries and convenient stores nearby. The staff are helpful and friendly. The hotel advertises that they have laundry facilities so we didn’t pack as much as we should. But there’s only 2 coin-operated washing machines for the entire hotel so you have to be lucky to get to use it; try very early or very late at night! We stayed there for 9 nights so we had to do laundry on a few nights, sadly.They have an indoor onsen but it’s always quite crowded.All things considered, we’d stay there again if we go to Tokyo again. Just plan better in terms of clothes to bring.

Stayed here for 5 nights for business and has met with very good service from the ever friendly and polite staff. Very impressed with the service from the staff manning the front desk, seeing how they apologized to the customers to the extend they helped a customer that just arrived from a taxi.However the breakfast though ample but was boring as everyday were the same. I believed it was the same when I first stayed here 2 years ago for I remembered the stuff that was offered during that time. The numbers of TV channels available is still the same and there’s only 1 English channel, CNN.I hoped the hotel could improve on the shortcomings and build on the success of its staff.

The hotel's location is perhaps one of its greatest advantages, it's a walking distance from Hamamtsucho metro station and a walking distance from Ginza as well. The neighborhood is really nice and quiet.Service in the hotel is pretty good and consistent, the housekeeping however, was a bit of a hit and miss. Our room was pretty spacious. In general, our stay was very pleasant and we had a great value for our money. Will definitely stay again if we visited Tokyo again.

We stayed here for 4 nights when we first arrived in Tokyo. Location is in between two train stops - both a 10-15 min walk in different directions. The area was nice and clean (almost felt like a business area). The hotel was clean and the size of the room is what was expected based on pics/reviews and understanding we were in Tokyo. The shampoo, conditioner and body wash were my favorite of all the hotels we stayed at for our trip. Big thank you to a friendly staff that helped us book reservations. Even one who had run out of the hotel thinking we were heading in the wrong direction for one. Would definitely stay here again.

Mitsui Garden’s room are really spacious, specially for Japanese standards. I had a double room at 12th floor. Hotel is pleasant generally, small reception desk though which may cause some queue, but that is not a negative point. I enjoyed much my stay, good amenities, comfortable bed in a nicely decorated room close to Ginza and to subway. Hotel has a valuable restaurant with very varied breakfast buffet and dinner buffet (I didn’t try lunch). Buffet was varied and of a good quality, low presence of traditional food though but tasty anyways and at a very reasonable price.

We stayed in the hotel for 5 nights during our trip to Tokyo. It is within walking distance to Hamamatcho station (to take the monorail to and from Haneda International airport) ,also it is close to Daimon subway station and Shimbashi station. We booked a superior double room with king bed and it was very comfortable. Thank you for the nice service.

The hotel is located in a quiet neighbourhood, surrounded by what looks like a rather upscale apartments. It is around 400 m from Daimon Subway Station (with 2 subway lines) and 600 m from Shimbashi Station, which is a bigger station with 2 subway lines as well.Daimon Subway Station is just next to Hamamatsucho Station, where the monorail from Haneda Airport stops. If you are traveling using JR Train, both Hamamatsucho and Shimbashi station have JR Train stations there as well.Close by the hotel (around 1 minute walk) there is a 24-hour convenient store and if your hotel deal doesn't come with breakfast, you can buy some good sandwiches, fruit and yoghurt in the convenient store.Close by Shimbashi Station, there are quite plenty of small traditional Japanese pubs (called Izakaya), perfect to end your day.Check In was fast, however I found that the receptionists didn't speak English very well, even though we managed to get through without any issues.Room size was OK by Japanese standard and amenities were standard of a hotel of similar profile. The plus point of this hotel is that they have triple room (not a double room with 1 extra bed), which is perfect if you are traveling in a group of 3. Another positive aspect of this hotel is the availability of onsen (Japanese public bath) at the top floor. Please be mindful that male and female onsens are separated and you will need your room access card to enter the onsen. For this reason, the receptionist will ask how many men and women there are in your group and access cards will be marked based on gender.Overall, this hotel is suitable for those who prefer a quieter environment, but if you prefer a more vibrant environment, this hotel may not be your preferred choice

Stayed for 3 nights. Around 10 mins walk from Daimon. Quiet location. Very relaxing. Room was larger than expected. The photos looked like they’re tiny but was surprised of how much space we actually had. Room we stayed in was single but with a comfortable double bed. Smoking area at the back of the building. Public onsen at the top floor was awesome and clean.

We stayed here for 4 nights when touring in both Tokyo and Kamakura. It is located in this Shiodome area called Italia-gai where some buildings, restaurants are decorated with the certain Italian style. Real fun place to wander a little bit after an early check-in to taste the subtle colorfulness around. There are several metro stations nearby, including Shiodome, Hamamatsu, easy access to other parts of the city, say Asakusa and Ginza. It's also convenient for travelers like us going round way from/ to the Haneda airport, 30 to 35 mins tops. Speaking of the room, we ordered a king-size bed and it's comfortable for 2 persons plus 2 mid-sized pieces of suitcases. The hotel staff were friendly and helpful. We borrowed an umbrella for one day and enjoyed free luggage storage service for some hours after check out. The hotel is nice for the price.

Stayed for 2 nights. The room is smelly, and super tiny. The location is OK. But other than that there is nothing much positive to say. Very average hotel. Stay here only if u r going to spend the whole day outside and only come back to hotel late at night to sleep.

Even the hotel has a good location within Minato area and rooms are ok (just ok, tiny but is the regular size there); the a/c is set from a general control which I disliked; and my worst experience was at the restaurant, which is supposed to close at 10pm however they take the last guest at 9:30pm, but even one night I got there 9:05pm and waiters didn’t want to let me in me because they were “about to close”, after arguing and telling them I was a guest for the whole week and I knew already they take last guest at 9:30pm ( which is not shown in English anywhere by the way), they allowed me to come in. Where on earth you can’t get into a Buffet Restaurant one hour before official closing hours because they are “about to close”??? And it wasn’t even “a la carte” restaurant, all the food was already on the buffet.... the restaurant is a terrible experience.

This hotel was exactly what we needed for our 24 hour stay in Tokyo for a departure out of Haneda . We landed at Narita and flying out of Haneda early so we wanted to be close to Haneda, but still central enough to see other parts of Tokyo.The hotel is very nice for the price. Front desk was professional, but the 2pm check in we are getting at many hotels is just ridiculous! Anyway, the room was modern and spotless, very comfortable. The hotel is easy to get to, even with luggage, when arriving around morning rush hour and using public trans. Also close enough(5-7 miuntes walk) to Ginza, Shimbashi and Shiodome stations to get around and see other parts of Tokyo.Here's how.If you take the bus or limousine bus from Narita, its a 90 minute ride and you don't get dropped off too close to the Mitsui Garden hotel. If you take the Narita Express or the Skyliner Express(Expensive) you have to go to Tokyo station or Nippori station, then try to get on a full train in morning rush hour with your suitcase. its going to be very frustrating or impossible.If you take the Keisei Access train from Narita airport to Shimbashi station , about 75 minutes, you're the first on the train, don't have to change trains and its only 1330 Yen(@$12.00) From Shimbashi station to Mitsui Garden hotel its a 10 minute walk or $4 taxi ride.To get to Haneda airport, even early in the morning (there is a train that leaves at 04:59 and gets to Haneda airport at 05:17, less than 20 minutes) From Mitsui Garden hotel Shiodome, walk 7 minutes to Tokyo monorail hamamatsucho station and in 20 minutes you'll be at Haneda airport.

I stayed here for two nights in Tokyo before heading to Kanazawa. The location of the hotel is excellent. It is a 5 minute walk from Hamamatsucho Station on the Yamanote line. Meaning you are on the line for most of Tokyo tourist sites and Haneda Int. Airport.The other great thing about this hotel is the onsen. Free for guests. It was very hot in Tokyo while we were there so it was great to relax in the onsen in the evening. The rooms are basic but has everything you could need. We didn't use the breakfast as we thought it was a little too expensive so I can't comment on that. I would happily stay in this hotel again and would recommend it to friends.

The hotel rooms are quite big for Tokyo standard and the window is big enough to prevent you from feeling claustrophobic. The bathroom is super clean, and they provide big bottles of shampoo/conditioner/bath soap. The is also an ironing equipment in the room.I personally like the handy (mobilie phone) they provide in each room that is free roaming and internet for you to bring out during your stay. It certainly helped with the maps and city suggestions sites in the phone.We stayed for 3 nights, booked via Booking.com however we needed to extend one more night and booked another room from the same website, however the front office made it difficult for us and insisted in us checking out on 11am on the appointed day, and then re-check in at 3pm at the same hotel, in a different room.And when we talked at the front office the officers were not very friendly, no smiles, no apology, just matter-of-factly refused our request. This was the lowest point of our stay in this hotel. We personally think that the Japs need to relax and smile a little bit more to foreigners even though that is not in their own culture.Apart from that all normal, pleasant.

This hotel is within easy walking distance to Shimbashi and Shiodome stations making it ideal for travellers coming from Narita Airport or Tokyo station. The room was nicely sized and provided everything that we (a young couple) required. The staff all spoke English well enough and were happy to assist with anything we asked. All round a decent hotel if you're looking to stay in Tokyo for a reasonable price.

Stayed one night here on a business trip due to it being very close to the office I'm visiting. But I think I would find it to be a bit out of the way if I were visiting Tokyo as a tourist. The closest subway station is Daimon but I came via the Narita Express then transferred onto the Yamanote line to arrive at Shimbashi station, which is a good 15 minute walk to the hotel. As others have mentioned the hotel is located in a small neighborhood with cobbled streets (a bit of a challenge when you're walking with a luggage), Italian restaurants & cafes, which gives a bit of a European vibe. The property is small-to-mid size scale, allowing it to feel a bit more personal. The staff was what I found to be the highlight of my stay, especially the reception staff who were very welcoming and spoke excellent English. The room is typical-smallish size like most Japanese hotels. One note of caution, it is across the street from a fire station so you may here sirens.

Overall we enjoyed our stay but we believe there are room for improvements.Dislike:1. Blinds instead of Curtain..as sunrises at 4.30 am, sunray peep into the room.2. Only Eng TV channel is CNN. The rest are Japanese channels. Not user friendly for foreigners.3. No room service4. The walk to hotel were quiet during weekend as its mainly offices and residential building.Like:1. Onsen..use room key to enter and has all the amenities.2. Location - near to Hamamatsucho station which is convenient for monorail from Haneda airport and 2 subway lines.There is a convenient store just behind the hotel.3. Room - clean and big for Tokyo standard.

This was in a great location...just a short walk from the local Tokyo loop line and monorail from the airport. The room was a decent size AND they provided coffee bags...a rare event in our Japan travels.

This hotel was in a nice area, close to Ginza area, and provided all the basics. Nothing fancy or notable but everything was fine. The free phone to use for local calls and maps was a great amenity, too. Rooms were clean and comfortable. Front desk service was courteous; nothing special. Neighborhood is very cute, European-style, with two nice cafes nearby.

review_body: We stayed in February, 2018 for five nights and were very satisfied with our hotel selection. The hotel was located a few minutes walk from the monorail from Haneda, and was near the subway and JR lines. The room wasn’t large but reasonable enough for two people. The room had all kinds of gadgets....use of a cell phone, a speaker for an iPod, coffee / tea maker, and a hot water pot.....made use of all of these. WiFi was good and stable. Would stay here in future visits to Tokyo.

I thought the hotel was great value for money, spent two nights there. Service was good and rooms are small but with everything you might need. The only reason I am rating it as "average" is due to lack of Air-conditioning. There was a letter in the room apologizing for it, but once you are there, what can you really do? Only option was to open the window, and this was April, spring already.

First, the good stuff:The staff were helpful on the whole although seemed rather embarrassed to work there. The location is great, near the station and lots of restaurants. Having use of a smartphone is a nice touch. The room was unbearably hot. The average temperature in the room was 24-26°C, according to the room thermometer (the staff member we asked about this claimed this was incorrect and also offered to give us "the only fan in the hotel" as long as we kept it secret!) It appears that, rather than trying to rectify the problem (central setting of heating/air conditioning), the management has given staff stock phrases to use when guests (probably on a regular basis) complain. One of these is "The rooms are all the same temperature". Our daughter had her own room so we knew this wasn't the case. Opening the window was not an ideal solution as there is building work nearby and train tracks so it got quite noisy. The heating was centrally turned off on April 12th and the room temperature was ok after that. Unfortunately, our first few days in Tokyo were adversely affected as it was difficult to sleep.

We spend 3 nights staying in this hotel from Apri 11-13, 2018.First night we came in we complain about the air cond since they set up to heater. On the next day they change to cool.This hotel is near JR Yamanote line with station Hamamatsucho about 5 minutes walk. For those who have JR Pass may use this free line trip.Room is not big but better compare to other hotel in Tokyo but less restaurant in this area. You may go to Shimbashi about 10 minutrs walk.Going to Tsukiji is not far using subway. It is about JPY 180 for one trip. Station can be enter in Shiodome or Daimon.Price is competitive with tokyo and ginza area but you may have bigger room. All Mitsui personell may speak english. We also experience in Osaka. Room is good and clean. This hotel do not have swiming pool, sauna and gymnastic equipment. They just provide onsen facilities.They also provide coin laundry in Onsen changing room.

Central Air-conditioner system allows only 'heater on' without the option to switch to 'cooler on'. Found room too hot but unable to switch on cooler system. Need to open the window to allow cool air in but is so noisy. Will never return to this hotel.

This hotel should actually be quite good. Due to Management, it's not. I wouldn't stay here again.Let's start with the good...The rooms themselves are modern and fit-out is ok. Location is convenient, just 5-10mins walk from the subway stop "Hamamatsucho", which includes not only a metro stop, but also a stop on the direct skyrail to Haneda Airport. The staff are also friendly.HOWEVER...1. THE RIDICULOUS HEAT. This hotel was so unbearably uncomfortable to stay-in. No air-conditioning (due to a stupid central policy), with an explanation to just open a window - that then gives you the benefit of hearing trains run nearby.2. UNHELPFUL RESTAURANT 'ASSISTANCE'. I wanted to book a couple of restaurants during my stay, and given the language barrier, every other Japanese hotel I have ever stayed with is helpful in this regard. Not here though. They refuse to assist with any booking for a day upon which you arrive, or depart. So that dinner on my first night was only arranged through a long bumbling phone conversation in broken English and Japanese between myself and restaurant directly... with no assistance from the hotel. Luckily I was able to get the booking, but quite a nuisance.3. REQUEST CARD DETAILS. For the restaurant the hotel did book, they requested and received my credit card details on numerous occasions to secure the booking. I created a fuss after the 2nd time they requested them - just a pure waste of my time.4. MISTREATING MY BAGS. I arrived at 2:15pm, some 45 minutes before check-in opened. The hotel performed most of the actions, and said they will store my bags then take them to the room ready for my return after dinner at 10pm (when I could pick-up the room key). At my return to the hotel at 10pm, I was disgusted to see the bags had just sat in the hotel lobby for 8 hours, and nothing was prepared for me to go to.This is not an exhaustive list, but for a simple 2 nights stay I think I have said enough >/

the hotel was nice enough, but the room was hot. And this was in March! The staff suggested I open a window, and no less than 3 different printed sheets of paper also suggested this (which indicates this is a common, if not constant issue with guests) I opened a window, and discovered just how close the train lines are to the hotel. And also, an emergency vehicle station as well, is across the street. So there were very close trains, and very loud sirens going off all night long. When I asked the staff to turn on air conditioning for the room, I was offered a desk fan. The reviews online addressing this situation, have had many replies from the hotel management suggesting that if requested, the AC can be turned on for specific rooms as needed, and all the guest had to do would be to ask. This was not at all my experience, as I argued and pleaded with the front desk staff for the AC to get turned on, and I was refused repeatedly in no uncertain terms. The reality is that the hotel management, or staff, or both, are aware that their guests are uncomfortable in their hotel, and are still more interested in saving money, than in providing the basic attributes of any modern hotel, which are specifically offered by their hotel on all of the booking sites. So essentially, they lie to get you to book a room, and when you arrive, they refuse to provide basic services as advertised, and then when guests write negative reviews, they commonly go online and lie about whether they would have provided that service if only the guest had asked. If you don't provide air conditioning, and build a hotel near train tracks, and literally refuse to turn on the AC, guests should be made aware before staying at your hotel, plain and simple. After a night of lying awake listening to loud noise, I just booked another hotel for the remainder of my stay in Tokyo, and left. I prepaid, so I was out my $600, but at least I found a hotel that was comfortable enough to actually sleep in it, and enjoy my vacation, which is not a lot to ask really.

My usual roster of hotels were booked so ended up going here for 4 nights. The rooms were bigger than many of direct competitors and the bed was quite a bit softer (Japanese mattress are extremely firm). I also like that it has a sento-kai on 13F.Breakfast is more expensive than most hotels but I often just grab conbini food anyhow so no real loss here. The walk is a bit further from the station than i usually have but it is pretty close to both Shiodome & Hamamatsucho stations. Can also easily walk into Shinbashi.So all and all 4.5 Stars

Nice hotel, location is more or less ok. We didn’t try the breakfast because it was very expensive through the website of the travel agency. The room is small and the bathroom as well, but enough. The bed is small but very comfortable. But these are the standards in Japan

I went to Japan for business, I choose to stay at Mitsui Garden Hotel Shiodome because of a colleague reference. I can definitively confirm that it was the right choice. It is a nice business hotel with all the amenities needed while you are in a business trip, it is placed in a nice and quiet area. The rooms are nice, clean and the staff are friendly and accommodating. The only problem you face is that very few speak decent English, so many times be understood is a long and laborious process. Breakfast is served as buffet, and even if they try to offer also a continental version, it is not a glory. Anyway I found many more advantages than disadvantages so I think I will use it again when I come to Tokyo.

This is my first time to stay at this hotel, the room is spacious and in good looking. The location is a bit far from the metro station but it is acceptable. Compare to 4 stars hotel in Hong Kong, Staff Services and attitude are better than Hong Kong! Since I am also a Front Desk Supervisor in one of the 4'stars hotel in Hong Kong. Yet, hotel staff English learning need to be improve since i realized there were a lot foreign stay at your hotel!Overall it was a good experiences stay at your hotel!RegardsNick

We stayed four nights during a family vacation in Tokyo in January. We went to different Mitsui Garden hotels before and this one is located around 10~12 minutes walk from major station Shimbashi. The Shimbashi station has train routes connecting to basically anywhere within and outside Tokyo. We checked in before noon and was through efficient procedures,kept our luggage quickly and explained politely that our room will be available at 3pm. The room is well equipped with toiletries, humidifier, bottled water, coffee and tea are refilled upto for 3 people every day. Room size is not big but sufficient for moving around luggage and people. Clothing hanging and storage is relatively limited though. The window looks outside other commercial buildings yet not too close or pressed. Around the hotel there are sufficient choices of cafe and restaurants for a meal. We are fine to pull the luggage to and from the pebble stone road between the hotel and the station, but this could be a concern to others. All in all this hotel is an option in our future visit to Tokyo.

We stay in this hotel for 2 nights. It located in Shiodome, a very nice neighborhood. You can find lawson very near to the hotel. It is not so far away from the station ( shiodome and shimbashi) . You can find a very nice cars/supercars in the neighborhood especially at night.The hotel staffs are very helpful. I left my adaptor when i move to another hotel, and when i realized and call them, they still keep it .

I stayed at Mitsui Garden Shiodome Italia-gai for one week. The room was spotlessly clean. The bathtub was a bit small but probably adequate for people with smaller size. I ate one breakfast at the restaurant next to the lobby and the food was quite good. Now customer service was just top-notch. My company wanted a detailed receipt for reimbursement process and would not take the summarized one. I emailed a request to the hotel front desk and within an hour, they sent back a receipt with charges broken down for each day, even with an official stamped seal to prove its legitimacy. Now one would expect some request like that would take 1-2 days or a week for a response (if ever) in the US. Needless to say, Mitsui Garden customer support truly impressed me!

Not an airport hotel but very convenient for haneda airport. Everything you would expect from this standard of hotel, they will keep luggage. Excellent evening buffet - Italian themed and very reasonable.

Nice hotel with location very close to train station - about 5 min walk.Rooms are clean and well furnished. Staff is friendly and helpful.Breakfast is good and with many choices of different type of dishes.Wi-Fi is for free and works very well.

We stayed here for one night on arrival in Japan. It is easy to find and close to the Shinjuku Station and all that happens around it. It is really a well dressed budget hotel. Wi fi is free and signal strength is good. As always, you pay more in Japan than UK or the rest of Europe. Expect rooms to be small (double bed against a wall) and a tiny shower room. We did not have breakfast there as you could get anything you wanted at various eateries round and about the hotel for a fraction of the price. One note of caution is that the hotel is very close to the busy train lines and so there is constant train noise ( though to be fair most city hotels suffer in this way). In November there was no AC, just heating and it was very hot. When we complained and asked for the AC to be switched back on they told us to open a window- impossible with the constant train noise.

1st time to Tokyo and select this hotel as the accommodation.  Took around 1.5~2hours from the airport to the hotel as we just took the public transportation. Easy to locate the hotel from the JR station.  Quiet location but it still convenient as there are 3 convenient stores and restaurants (Japanese / Coffee Shop / 24hours McDonald / Ramen) nearby.  For the hotel services, the staff can speaks in English and we received a warm welcome from them. Staff will also suggest the restaurants nearby with the map, it is quite good! For the rooms, as we reserved 2 Rooms, 1 for 3PAX and 1 for 2PAX. To be honest, the 3PAX room is quite small and did not have much space the walk through and quite tight to open the suitcases. For the 2PAX room is much better and it also with a nice Tokyo Tower view as it located on a higher floor.  For the prices, is a reasonable price and I will suggest people who travel with friends and stay most of the time outside would be a great option to choose this hotel as it does not have many hotel facilities and not that convenient for elderly.

The Mitsui Garden Hotel Shiodome is located a few minutes' walk from some small shopping streets, and not far from good small restaurants - but not close to any major tourist sites. However, the metro system is easy, extensive, quick and not expensive (buy the multi-use day pass, not individual tickets) so it's simple to move around. The room was small, and the A/C did not work, so it got stuffy unless you opened the window and let in cooler air and Tokyo noise. It was okay but not more than that. The 13th floor Japanese bath is supposed to be very good, but I did not use it - too tired and too busy.

If I could I would have rated the hotel as "good" (not very good)The rooms are comfortable, although a bit small (but so frequent in Tokyo), and even the bed size is limited. Bathroom is small but clean and all amenities provided.Convenient location / walking distance from GinzaMany good restaurants within a 20 mns walk radiusWe did not try the breakfast in the hotel but you have very good coffee shops less than 5 mns awayStaff was very friendly and welcoming

We did not expect such a spacious room in Tokyo. With good layout of bed and sideboard, we could put out 2 large suitcases and still have room to move around and work at the desk. And we got a comfortable room with morning light and a view - it is of the train lines far away and open space, instead of other tall buildings. It is a 10-minute walk to Hamamatsucho Station which got us to connections to all the major sightseeing sites. The Hamarikyū Garden, Tokyo's largest strolling garden is well within walking distance. And we could walk to Tsukiji Market if we wanted to (about 30 mins).Pleasant staff and bright reception area.

We have stayed here for 5 nights as part of our honeymoon. First of all, the rooms. The room per se is okay, I’ve realized that the room size standard in Japan is smaller than other places but having stayed at the Hilton Odaiba a month prior, the room felt pretty small. One side of the bed is touching the wall and the wardrobe is okay for 7-8 hanging clothes. Mostly clean, although the duvet has a “whatever-that-was” stain and some of the walls had stains if you look closely. On the bright side, the bed is comfortable and not as stiff as other hotels in Japan. They also left a Japanese charger with iphone connector, which is a nice detail.The bathroom. Is something I still can’t understand. In the two hotels we have stayed here in Japan the bathrooms look all plasticky and construction site-like bathroom. Also not fit for two at the same time. Clean though.Breakfast and service. We had breakfast included at “La Marea”, which pretends to be an Italian restaurant. The choices of european-style food were not so many (some croissants, bread, bacon and eggs) and as most of the customers are asian, I guess that is what you get. The staff speaks poor english, although they try hard to help as much as possible.The location is somewhat convenient as you are close to Ginza and 10 minute walk to two JR/metro stations.Wouldn’t recommend for someone used to European/american standards.

borjasamso
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: We really enjoyed our stay here at one of the Mitsui Garden hotels in Tokyo. The location was great and allowed straightforward access to the subway line and the rest of the city.Staff could not have been more helpful and made us feel welcome throughout. Our room was comfortable and a nice temperature. I believe Japan is known for slightly smaller room size than perhaps some other countries and we did notice this, but there was still plenty of space for our luggage etc.There were a number of local restaurants and bars at our disposal, however we generally opted to venture to a variety of other districts as we like to explore!Overall a pleasant stay and we would happily return in the future. Thank you!Benedict & Sharon

We recently stayed 1 night at this Hotel as it was very convenient for catching the Monorail to Haneda. It was in a lovely neighbourhood with plenty of restaurants nearby. Very quiet streets when walking to the Station. Our rooms were very small with the bed against the wall which made it difficult for one person to get out so we did move the bed away from the wall. Cosy bathroom with adequate amenities. We did not use the public bath as there seemed to be a lot of Chinese staying in the hotel but the instructions for use were very good.

Nice hotel in a very calm central part of Tokyo! Only 10 minutes on foot to the station for express trains to the airport, which is very comfortable. The staff is very helpful, all the amenities included. You can also use public bath in the hotel. The location is also extremely good to visit all the main sightseeings in Tokyo:)

The hotel is a business hotel. The rooms are ok not small clean bright and quiet. Slept very well. The AC works beds a little hard. Bath works great furnished with tooth brushes. I enjoyed my stay. The service was friendly. The restaurant service is buffet.

The Hotel is located in the center of Tokyo, near the JR Hamamatsucho station and the Oedo subway just few minutes walk. Very convenience for transportation around Tokyo and nearby. The Hotel is very clean and prompt service. Breakfast is excellent with lot of variety food choices.Surrounding area is very quite and beautiful for take a walk or photo-taking.Once is not enough!!

The hotel small, quaint and a little off the beaten track was a nice hotel, the food in the evening was of an excellent standard and the cleanliness to an exceptional standard.I would recommend and stay there again.

My daughter picked this hotel based on ratings, location, and price. It was a hit. Location: a bit of a walk from the Hammamatsucho station. It's a level path on the street, but the station entrance at the nearest street to the hotel has stairs. If you walk down the "alley" right of the station, about 1/2-way to the end of the building, and on the RIGHT, there's an elevator. Do take the time to find the hotel on the map, and locate the subway station, and get an idea of how to proceed. You can't see the hotel from the station. GPS via smartphone helps!The hotel is located in what some have called Tokyo's Italian Quarter. There are Italian themed restaurants nearby, and even the hotel's restaurant is Italian, although it's a buffet. There's a Lawson's combini in the adjacent building. Very handy.Because of the 2020 Olympics, there is a large construction project on the next block, and there is some construction noise that leaks into the rooms. It's not a factor for us, but if you're a light sleeper, it may be. The hotel is upfront about the noise.The rooms were comfy and spacious. Beds were comfortable, but the pillows are a buckwheet/conventional hybrid, so you might want your own. Bathroom has a tub/shower, and a washlet toilet. There's a desk, a hotel provided cellphone/device charger, and sufficient power connections. Wifi reaches the room.On the 13th floor, there are men's and women's spas, and a single washer/dryer machine in each spa. These are single-unit combo machines, clothes go in dirty and come out clean and quasi-dry. The downside is the machines are slow (about a 2-hour cycle). I don't recall the cost, bring 100-yen coins. Detergent is provided. You'll probably need at least one extra dry-only cycle. They also have a laundry service if DIY isn't your style.There are many restaurants and bars along the streets from the subway station. Byron Bay coffee is on the way to the station, and that became our morning coffee stop. Great coffee drinks there. Tokyo is huge, and I confess to never eating at any of the restaurants near the hotel.The hotel staff is conversant in English, and very helpful. The pictures here are accurate, although we had no problem with bugs. I'll stay there again.

Stayed here 1 night before I flew back to Europe and this hotel was everything I expected. Nice and clean rooms with all the comfort you need. The hotel is situated in quite a chique area and I had the impression that it's a neighbourhood with offices. Staff was very friendly and always willing to help. I also enjoyed the hot tub on the 13 th floor. Would go there again.

good location clean rooms nice onsen, however very bad customer service and very unhelpful reception staff. We had a 10pm flight and they would not allow us to use the empty onsen or take a shower and change there either, very unhelpful and won't be staying there again

I'd definitely stay at the Mitsui Garden Hotel Shiodome Italia-gai again, and I'll bullet-point our experience here.- The hotel is ever-so-slightly out of the way, however I feel this is in its benefit. It is a 5-10min walk (with luggage, less without) from Daimon station, which has very good and very reasonable pubs/restaurants. It is a 5min walk from Shiodome, which is slightly more upscale but still has very good and very reasonable restaurants. It is 15min walk from Ginza (Tokyo's 'Manhattan', as it were). You won't find a better deal at a better hotel any closer to Ginza. Plus, you get the benefit of three distinct locations from this hotel.- The hotel is lovely, very well-maintained, with friendly, approachable, helpful, and multilingual staff.- The room was very nice, large for a central Tokyo hotel, and equipped with all amenities you'd expect from a hotel of this kind, and includes Nespresso machine, with complimentary tabs, WiFi, Bluetooth speaker system, television, safe, wardrobe. The bathroom was slightly small, but unless you're 6'3"+ and well-built, it's no issue. Great shower. We had a non-smoking room, though smoking rooms are available.- The breakfast has a great range but goes a little bit awry with its flavours for western visitors. A better option is to use your breakfast vouchers for lunch service, which is more conventional (if you prefer Western food - otherwise, the Japanese selection was excellent). The range of desserts is exceptional.- There is a very good convenience store next door (a Lawson Natural, open 24 hours), an outdoor pizzeria on the other corner of the square, and a very well-equipped supermarket next to that.- The area is quiet and very well-maintained. It has the layout and plan of a European square, with the hotel on one corner of the square. It's very nice and adds to the appeal of the hotel.- There is a traditional Japanese spa, free to use for guests, which is a great bonus and adds something different to the appeal of this hotel.

We stayed here for one night only before our flight home. The staff were very friendly and helpful, and were more than happy to look after our luggage before check-in and after check-out. We didn't stay long enough to make use of any facilities (which is a shame because they looked good), so all I can rate is the room itself. Unfortunately, it was not good. We booked a triple room (3 adults), but the room was barely big enough to fit the three beds. There was no room whatsoever for our suitcases. We had to keep them zipped up and standing vertically against the wall at the foot of our beds and could then just get through without climbing over the beds. It looked like a third bed had been squeezed into a small double room, rather than being a true triple room. We were glad we were only staying one night. The wardrobe was barely big enough for two, let alone three, but we were not unpacking so this didn't bother us too much. The toilet was in the same room as the shower, making the morning routine a slower process for three of us.The hotel is easy walking distance from both the subway (Daimon) and JR (Hamamatsucho) stations and we had no trouble wheeling our luggage to and from. The hotel itself may have been fine if we'd booked two rooms, but it is definitely not suitable for three in one room. In summary: Don't advertise and sell us a triple room if you don't actually have one!

Stayed here for 3 nights on business and found the area nice and quiet though there's a fire station beside and a hospital nearby. Not forgetting the train tracks were not far away too.The room is rather of a good size for Tokyo having stayed in other hotels in Japan and it was comfortable and quiet. Check-in and out was rather quick unless you met a group of tourists then you'll have to wait but all 3 counters are always manned. The staff could speak rather well in English so I had no problem asking them for some info about the area.Stepped out of the hotel and one can find many restaurants within walking distance and the Daimon station, Hamamatsucho Monorail and JR Yamanote Line is about 5-10 mins walk away. It took me about 15-20 mins to walk to Ginza shopping area.Wifi connection is good but only CNN is the only English channel I can find. No problem for me as I'm not there to watch TV shows.Overall a good stay I would say for a business traveler.

Great mid range hotel. Located in a business district, which means you are out of the busyness of Tokyo, but still in a great location with fab restaurants and an easy walk to at least two train stations. Hit and miss with english speaking staff, however not a problem as regardless of language ability staff are super helpful and polite. Rooms are smallish but very clean and exceptionally well appointed. Free Wi-Fi is a big bonus. Just wasn't brave enough to try the Bath House. Maybe next time?!

Toni P
Auckland Central, New Zealand

review_body: First; huge line for the check inSecond; people at front desk barely spoke proper EnglishThird; there was no soap at the bathroomFourth and last; today at the shower and unexpected/wanted companion...roach!!!I go downstairs to check out and complain and the only answer is sorry sir room is already paid.This is the one and last time I will stay in this unusual bad service hotel in TokyoPrevious experiences during last 15 years have been great!I love this country and its people but this Japanese-Italian whole will not see me again.

Stayed here on the last night of Golden Week here in Japan. It is a very comfortable hotel, in a easy to reach location. The rooms are big and comfortable. The staff is friendly and helpful. There is a Japanese style bath on the top floor, which is really nice to relax in after a long day of sightseeing, work, or whatever tires a weary body.

Booked 2 night stay upon arriving in Tokyo from 11 hour flight . Clean hotel, comfortable beds, nice amenities. Terrific central location, can take train from airport. Excellent rate for such nice hotel. We would recommend it to all our friends. Resting here was a great way to overcome jet lag... some Japanese language would be helpful.

For usd 200/night you get a decent room with two separate or one double bed. Room is not big and closet only has six hangers for two and the bathroom is not for tall guests. But on the positive side, it is very clean, has a good breakfast though typical Japanese. The hotel has a public bath on the top floor. The hotel is next to a fire station but during the week we stayed there we never heard a siren - so no false alarms or real fires for that matter. Many westerns stays at the hotel and sometimes the queue in front of breakfast could be long. The hotel is 10 minutes walk from Ginza and about same to the fish market. Our room was facing the Tokyo-tower which is a great sight when dark. Very friendly reception and staff who spoke good English.

Just spent a week with a family in Tokyo, and despite of a very large amount of hotels and different areas, we were very pleased of our choice, Mitsui Garden Shiodome italia-gai. There was five adults in our group and we had a need for two rooms, one for two and one for three adult. I was a bit skeptic beforehand, what kind of room we will get for three, but i was positively surprised. Room for three had three decent big bed, and we still managed to place our three suitcase also there.Hotel was quite easily able to reach by metro, we used Daimon station a lot. Also it was quite easy to travel from and to Narita, Narita express to Tokyo station, and then few stops by Yamanote-line to Hamamatchuco station. Surrounding area was a bit more peaceful compared to some other areas, and we appreciated it. But there was still restaurants on this area, and for us, Ginza-area was on the walking distance.The one thing, we maybe were a bit dissapointed on here, was breakfast. It was a bit too japanese for us, we expected it to be a bit more eauropean. But as it is said "when in Japan, do as the Japanese do"There was a free wifi on all areas at the hotel, and it did work perfectly.Overall hotel was very clean, staff was very nice. There was also a small spa, but we did not test it. But i would say that I could come back in this hotel, if travelling again.

The location is in a business area in a quiet neighborhood. About 500m walk to train and subways. Many choices of restaurants and convenience stores around. We loved that you could escape from busy streets after a long day out. The hotel was in great condition overall, quite new, clean and the room was spacious compared to most. We had been to much worse. We loved the onsen, nice, neat and clean. Wifi was great. Staff were friendly, effective and very helpful. Only thing we did not like was the aircon was set to cooling or heating only. We had some warm nights during spring and we had to turn it off and left the window open. Last time that happens we complained to the staff and were offered a fan, which was great! It was our 5th stay there.

This is moderate hotel.Reasonable walking distance to several rail/metro stations, so access to Tokyo sites etc is fine.Things we did not like:# very small room (even after upgrade). Double bed against a wall means nocturnal toilet visits require gymnastic ability and/or competence in 'partner clambering'.# inflexible air conditioning policy means the centrally controlled system only provides warm air until mid-April, then only cool air after that. As it hit 25C in the 'warming period', the room became very hot. Sleeping difficult as window had to be closed at night due to construction work over the road.# the only pillows available provided little or no support and contained what felt like large bits of beanbag fill.What did we like?#as in all the Japanese hotels we stayed in, the staff were friendly, courteous and as helpful as they could be.# the room was clean#the buffet breakfast was consistent if limited in range.#great view of Tokyo Tower from room windowFor tourists this is a well located hotel in a very pleasant area. If you can select the 'right' room with an appropriate configuration of bedding, you could do a lot worse.

This modern high-rise hotel has comfortable clean rooms with free wifi and helpful staff. There is only one restaurant which runs buffet style dining through the day: the food is OK but nothing special. The top floor includes a communal bathing facility.

Good comfortable rooms and didn't have any issues with noise. A bit of a walk to restaurants and shopping areas, perhaps around 20 minutes. However not too far from Shiodome or Daimon subway stations and quite close to the monorail which is handy for the airport.

First off, don't book a smoking room if you do not smoke. I have stayed in three other Mitsui Garden Hotels and enjoyed staying in each of them and so Mitsui Garden is always on the top of my list, so top that I booked a smoking room because all non-smoking ones were booked, hoping the ventilation system + air purifier would do the job but I was SO wrong - the whole room, in fact the entire 6th floor smelled of cigarette I had to wear a mask to sleep (This is my part and I don't blame anyone).We had to open the windows in the room to let fresh air in - there the major problem lied - our room faced the construction site and the railway and it was noisy from morning (8-ish am) till midnight. Request a room that faces the west / north to avoid the noise.Very good service, helpful staff, big room, clean bed and bathroom. The water pressure in the room was weak so we preferred using the public bath. The public bath was however small and could get very crowded at night. Two nights out of three nights I had to queue up (nude) to shower.It's a short walk from several stations metro / JR stations to the hotel, the neighbourhood is quiet and nice to walk in it. However, I would prefer a hotel that's closer to the station if it's raining season / very cold.

Let me start off this review with a few caveats: 1) My wife and I love the Hamamatsucho/Shinbashi area. Our 3rd Tokyo visit in 5 years and still can’t think of a better place to stay 2) We love walking in Tokyo, regardless of temperature & weather. 3) We did not stay in the basic room. We stayed in the superior double which came with its own Nespresso coffee machine, which made a whole world of difference as you would see later in the review.Mitsui Garden is located in the Hamamatsucho/Shinbashi vicinity. It is a quiet, charming part of Tokyo, apparently with some Italian connections, and hence its name. Location-wise, it’s perfect for us! True that it’s not really near any subway/JR train stations. Google Map puts it at 600-700m away from Hamamatsucho station, which is about 5-6 min walk away. Even with our luggage (albeit only one piece), it’s pretty manageable. There are a number of charming hole-in-the-wall eateries and cafes along the way to cater to all whims and fancies. We had lunch at one of the stand-up udon stalls. Fantastic food. In the other direction, it’s about 10-15 minutes’ walk from Shinbashi with its endless variety of eateries, watering holes and izakayas. This distance can get to some stopover guests but for us, it’s a big plus as it allows us to walk off our dinner/drinks (see caveat above) and put a physical distance between the Shinbashi crowds/bedlam and us.The room was a decent size for a Tokyo hotel, in fact a bit on the generous side. Our room came with a Nespresso machine and 4 capsules which were topped up daily. The average temperature in the mornings during our 4-day stay was 1 degree Celsius. The Nespresso saved our lives by giving us our daily coffee fix in the comfort of our own room. We could buy in some simple bites from the Lawson next door for a quick breakfast. It also boasted of a Sony Bluetooth speaker which allowed us to play our favourite tunes in a foreign room. Awesome! The pillows were a bit flat and hard and not very comfortable for both of us. As mentioned by some reviewers, it did get a bit noisy when some of the more inconsiderate guests returned to their rooms. Didn’t really get out of hand though, just a bit annoying.Staff spoke good English and generally very helpful. We were going to Hakushu Whisky Distillery and my wife emailed them to assist with a reservation at the White Terrace restaurant. Reply email came on the same day with the reservation made.In short, we have found our default go to Tokyo hotel. The price-value proposition and the whole package works really well for us. We are more than won over by the nice touches that the hotel offer for a reasonable price. Everyone has his/her own favourite area in Tokyo and Shinbashi/Hamammatsucho is not for everyone. But if you are looking for a more than decent room here at a good price, look no further than Mitsui Garden Shiodome.Tips: 1) A cab ride from the hotel to Tokyo Monorail at Hamamatsucho is 410 yen, which is the flag down fare. We were leaving at 6 am and decided not to wake the neighbourhood with our luggage.2) A couple of eateries worth trying are Akitaya 秋田屋 at Hamamatsucho, Rose and Crown pubs. There are a number of them scattered around Shinbashi, Yaesu, Tokyo station area. The steak roast went perfect with Suntory's Master Brew, especially in a chilly spring night.

Great room, large by Japanese standards. 10 mins walk from Hamamatsucho station, and from shimbashi station - easiest to find from the former. Convenient by western standards, not for the Japanese hence the lower price. Next to the Japanese horseracing federation offices.

Stayed here multiple times, last time with my girlfriend, rooms are quiet And clean, at first we had a misinterpretation of prices on booking.com, leading to an additional bill of 280 euro (300 usd) over 5 nights. This was however kindly solved without paying extra when we arranged a japanese speaking person to explain our situation. Other than that; convenient hotel near shinbashi area at a fair price.

The room is modern with all the amenities, however the check-in was an average experience, staff give you the keys and explained rules of using the hot tub, overall they are friendly and helpful. Location like all others have said, central but a good 10 min walk from nearest station. There isn't a hotel shuttle service. The biggest problem I have is the noise outside of the window and inside the hotel. There are people opening and closing doors and walks around at my floor constantly after 12:00 am. I decided to put a call to the front desk, the staff was helpful and said he will try his best to stop the noise. Maybe try to locate relatives and friends to inter joining rooms instead of having them walk around visiting neighbours late in the evening?!?!

First thing that I didn't like about this hotel is that they charge the full amount of your stay upon arrival where other hotels would take a deposit. Secondly, you cannot stand up straight in the shower if you are taller than 185cm. The towels are also in proportion to that. And the pillows have something like little balls in them and are not comfortable at all. The good thing about this hotel is that it's clean and priced reasonably.

The hotel was pretty centrally located, and while it wasn't too far from the closest location it wasn't that close either. We certainly noticed the distance when bringing all our luggage to catch the plane.In terms of the actual room, it was very clean and while it wasn't big, there was still enough room for two people.

This hotel is not too far from the station, but not that close. The room was nice but not memorable. The service was basic, not fantastic. It was fine but we won't come back. The price wasn't worth just fine.

I stayed in Mitsui Garden Hotel Shiodome Italia-gay more than one time and I think the right definition for this hotel is excellent, but with some weak points. Rooms are excellent and sufficiently large, the free public bath is wonderful and the service is always polite with staff who speak good English. The hotel location is excellent: ten minute walk from Shimbashi and Ginza areas. The JR station is a 5 min walk away (with luggage), ideal if you have the JR pass. The district around is sufficiently served with restaurants, but if you move to Shimbashi area you can find much better options, including very typical restaurants.Breakfast is expensive and offer poor value for money. What is funny is that it is served in an Italian restaurant, but if you ask for espresso coffee, you are even charged at the top for it! So breakfast should be definitively avoided, also because there any many alternatives coffee shops all around the hotel.The price of hotel in some cases is good in other cases too high. At the end the hotel is recommended, but only if price is convenient.

I choose this property because I have been staying another hotel nearby for the past and want to see how this is.First of all, access is really easy that within10 mins on foot from Hamamatsucho Station. Head from north from the station, find World Trade on your left then cross the road at your 3 o'clock then straight forward. I do not expect the room is really trendy, tidy, spacious and comfortable. And a free bottle of drinking water.A restaurant at the 1/F (ground level) but a pity that I do not have chance to with it food and service. However the charges for breakfast is reasonable.I stay one night there and I already recommend to my teamates.

Although the hotel name has Shiodome in it, it is closer to Hamamatsucho JR and Daimon Metro stations. It is also within walking distance of Shiodome and Shinbashi stations, although when it's cold out, the walk seems long. You can also walk to Ginza. The restaurant is buffet style & rather expensive, but lots of great, small restaurants within walking distance. There is a 24 hour Lawson's located conveniently in the building next door. There is a large public bath and a washer & dryer on the 13th floor. Overall, a great value, with good size room & all necessary amenities including coffee, tea, hair dryer, toiletries, etc.

Room size is budget style. Location is good, near Hamamasutcho station. Friendly and helpful staffs. Hotel nearby nice ambient and scenery with eateries, restaurants. Overall, a safe stay. Will consider back again.

We use this hotel during our seminar in the nearby Jikei University. This a modern hotel with moderate room size at around 21 m2, which is pretty decent considering the small room size in most hotel in Japan. There is an italian restaurant in the lobby serving all you can eat lunch & dinner that we didn't try. And there is also a natural Lawson nearby and some other convenience store that we found about 2-3 blocks from the hotel. There is a construction site across the street but they didn't bother us. Hamamatsucho station, which is part of the Yamanote line and Monorail line to the Haneda is nearby and within walking distance. Also the Shidome station that can take you to the Odaiba area with the Rainow bridge, Liberty statue by using the Yurikamome line. There is a safe deposit box inside the room, it is a plus for me.

This is a small, mid-range hotel that is close not a far walk from landmark Tokyo Tower. We stayed here for one night (upon arrival). It wasn't a far walk from the train station, after arriving from our flight into Narita (train transfer from Narita to this area). The hotel was about 3 blocks from the station, and is a very walkable area. This is the "Italian" part of Tokyo - Italian names of shops and restaurants. Even the hotel has an Italian restaurant. There is a pants press machine in your room, as well as a coffee maker and coffee cups. This hotel has a bath house, where it is full nude but there is no charge to use. This hotel provides appropriate apparel to wear to the bath house, along with all the rules (BE ADVISED: no tattoos, no washing of hair, no swimwear allowed). Small hotel room, so enough floor space to open 2 large luggages, and your floor is covered. Something neat about this hotel, is that they print your room number on your room key, as well as if the key is for male or female. This is the same key that will power on the lights in your hotel room, as well as the key to grant you access to the bath house.

Stayed here for 3 nights for business. Compared with many mid range hotels in this area l, good point of this hotel is the value for money. For the same facilities, this hotel is a bit cheaper than others. Bad point is, it is not so convenient. This area is very quiet and it takes more than 10min walk to the nearest train station or a major restaurant area. So if you can compromise the convenience and want to enjoy a modern mid range hotel in this Ginza-Shinbashi-Hamamatsucho area, this is not a bad choice.

Spent three nights in this hotel located close to the Ginza district. Rooms as well as bathrooms are quite small like most of the hotels in Japan. Employees at the front desk speak good English (seldom) and are very helpful. The breakfast is very local with little, sweet western food.

We recently enjoyed an overnight stay at the Mitsui Garden Hotel. We were looking for a hotel that was close to the monorail terminal at Hamamatsucho as we were arriving late from the airport. The hotel proved an ideal choice being an easy 400m walk from the NE exit. Take the cross walk under the railway bridge and then, keeping the railway on your right, just continue straight up the side street, the road eventually turns to the left and voila! you're at the hotel. We did this walk at 11pm at night and felt entirely safe. Hotel itself was clean and presentable and has all the amenities, we requested two adjoining non smoking rooms, which we got (don't take this for granted in Japan). The rooms are small but adequate. There is a Lawsons and a 7-11 within a couple of minutes walk. For the cost we were happy with our overnight stay. If you want another alternative in the same area check out reviews of Mystays Premier, very similar location but you need to navigate the labyrinth of back streets to find it from the monorail terminal.

Selected this hotel as a transit/ last stop before flying out of Tokyo. Its' location is not bad and the vicinity has a number of eateries. However, I did not get the opportunity to try the food as I was there on New Year Day.. where everywhere was closed as the locals travel out of Tokyo.. Bed and amenities are pretty standard - nothing much to shout about.The hotel does has a small restaurant that serve buffet but I would suggest that one should look around elsewhere first.. there are much better and cheaper ones around the hotel. The hotel also has an Onsen but it is quite small - it is probably designed for not more than 6 persons..

The location is about 10 mins walking from Shinbashi Station. While doing check-in, The staff was very friendly and explain everything to us, but while doing check-out, I tried to borrow a umbrella from them because it was heavy rain out side, but was told I need to buy it for 500 yen. I saw other hotel guests borrow the umbrella from the front desk like 5 mins ago, and I need to buy it? I also asked the staff to call a cab for us, but they told me the connection is not working, I saw other guests has the cab to pick them up. I think they need to training the staffs to have better service and attitude!

We chose this hotel in our recent trip to Japan for the first 2 nights in Tokyo due to it's availability for a triple room and the reasonable price we got. The hotel has a modern look and located in a quiet area. It seems to be popular with the business travel crowd. The room is small but well furnished for a comfortable stay ( small fridge, security safe, free wifi, yucata etc...). There's a free japanese bath (onsen ?) available for guest on one of the top floor. It's worth trying if you have not yet experienced it. The hotel has a restaurant on the lobby level which serves breakfast/lunch/dinner. Around the hotel, if you walk toward Daimon subway station, there's a lot of interesting hole in the wall restaurants. We ran into a small yakitori place ( Japanese name with a 100 yen sign) where we had feasted on yummy chicken meat and offal skewers for a very reasonable price. Tsutsuji fish market is about 15 minutes walk, and Ginza area is just a little bit further.Overall we had a good stay at this hotel and would recommend it.

Found this hotel on TA, liked the fact that it's walking distance to the Hamamatsucho monorail station from Haneda and its public bath. We arrived early so check in was a problem, it would turn out that almost all hotels in Japan are very strict about the 3 pm check in time. We finally checked in at 12 noon and had to pay and extra 3000 yen for "early check in". Other than that, this was a good choice. Room was rather small but not oppressively so, the double bed was somewhat larger than expected, nice comfortable beddings, shower was good, deep bathtub, electric kettle, little fridge and safe in room. And quite importantly, free wifi was quite fast. Building's not very tall so not much of a view from any room, but higher would be better as you'd get more light, we had room 1023 which was fine. And this being Japan everything's exceedingly clean. About the area, it's in a quiet new development, all new European style buildings, and the street the hotel was not named "Italia-gai (Italian street) for nothing. Quite a few restaurants and coffee shops around, in fact the most concentration of western restaurants compared to any other neighborhood in Tokyo. A 10-15 minute walk will bring you to either the busy area of Shimbashi with tiny traditional Japanese restaurants under the train tracks or malls with newer restaurants and shops, and in 20 minutes you would reach Ginza. So while the hotel is not right in the middle of everything it's certainly close enough. There is also a convenience store Lawson's right next to the hotel for drinks and snacks - try the egg custards they were delicious!The hotel itself has an Italian restaurant, serving three buffets a day. Tried the breakfast which had more Japanese dishes than western ones but try at least once it would be interesting. More than that it could get boring as nothing changed much from day to day. If feeling adventurous and looking for local ambience, try the little places under the tracks - might not have English menus but most have realistic plastic models of the dishes and clearly marked prices.

Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Location was easy to get to from Haneda Airport - just take the monorail to the last stop Hamamatsucho Station about 20mins by the rapid train (JPY490 only) but you will have to walk 650m with your luggage to the hotel which is in a very quiet area. It's a lot easier on the wheelies if you roll them along the road rather than on the pavement. There was no much traffic along the side road leading from the World Trade Centre to Mitsui Garden. After 4 days - this little walk was not a problem.Rooms are standard - we had one triple room and one double room next to each other. Not much space to leave luggage open in the triple room but we managed. Bed was comfy - aircon was working - bathroom facilities all working with hot water.Lawson's store was just in the next building if you need to stock up on basic morning foods. There's a Cafe Byron (very Australian) along the way to the train station and lots of little ramen eateries as well.This is my first time flying in via Haneda & whilst it's only 20mins & cheaper getting into Tokyo via the monorail - I somehow still prefer flying in via Narita & taking the train (costs about double or more) into Ueno & staying at the Mitsui Garden Hotel Ueno.

This definitely isn't the Four Seasons, but let's face it...if you're looking to book at the Four Seasons you wouldn't be looking at Mitsui Garden at all, right? lol The Mitsui Garden Shiodome Italia Gai is very clean, quiet, ideally located, and affordable. The property is within walking distance of Ginza, and Shimbashi & Hamamatsucho Stations which is ideal if you have a JR Pass. There's also a Lawson's conbini right next door and a 7/11 only 7 mins away (on foot). I booked a twin double room (including breakfast) and was pleasantly surprised by the size of the room. I was expecting smaller but there was plenty of room and I slept quite comfortably. The staff is great, very friendly, knowledgeable and everyone spoke English. The first morning there was a bit of confusion regarding breakfast as the front desk staff didn't give us any breakfast voucher when we checked in the evening before. The situation was quickly remedied with little fuss and a lot of apologies and while not necessary, they were appreciated. The breakfast was a mix of Western & Japanese food and was always fresh and delicious. When I visit Tokyo again, I would definitely consider staying at this hotel.

We were very pleased with the rooms and the service. When I got up jet lagged at 3:30 AM local time and couldn't find my key, the front desk helped cheerfully. Also, when we were confounded by the coffeepot, someone came up to the room and showed us the trick. A very nice place.

This Mitsui Garden is great for business travelers that aren't willing to splurge on hotel budgets. Located near the business district of Shiodome its one of the more affordable options in Tokyo. This was a fairly quiet and peaceful subsection of Shiodome, contrasting to the busier and more metro Shiodome area. Although its located in between 3 metro stations, drawback was that its at least 7-8 minutes or more walk away from any of them so if you aren't willing/able to walk its going to be a setback. Around 25 minutes walk away from the famous fish market Tsukiji fish market.There aren't a whole lot of restaurants (especially local ones) nearby so you might need to again walk a bit to grab a bite. There's a Lawson's convenience store nearby and it could probably solve most needs.I didn't try the hotel restaurant and it probably didn't warrant a try anyway.Room was spacious (for Tokyo/Japan standards) and was enough for me and my gf.Typical Japanese bathroom set (felt like it was those stock/removables) slightly small compared to the room itself, very hard for 2 people to navigate in.Shower Amenities are the big bottled sharing pump types so if you are picky in having small little sample sized bottles this may not be for you.No fancy service, but this is all you need simplicity.Overall this was great value for money. Would definitely consider again if for business. For travellers, if you don't mind the walk and its not very exciting (on the quiet side) around the hotel then worth a try especially for the price.

Still one of my best and favorite places in Tokyo. Affordable, great staff, nice rooms (albeit Japanese style so BE CAREFUL they are not as spacey as they are in the US or Europe), lovely public bath on top of the building. I am deducting a star this time because the wi-fi system seemed to work very poorly after 19.00, presumably because there are more people back to the hotel and the server might be overloaded. This is something that I experienced also in other occasions since I visit the hotel recently and they should address the issue. Either than that it's simply a wonderful place.

I chose this hotel because it was a reasonable price and central to my needs while in Tokyo. (I was also attending an event at the Tatsumi Swimming Centre.)The staff were very helpful and polite whenever I needed assistance.The room was of a good size and spotlessly clean, with pajamas and slippers provided, along with bathroom supplies and bottled water. The bed was very comfortable and the pillow great as I lIke a harder pillow.The hotel was close to the subway - several lines a short walk - and I used the subway extensively.There is also a buffet restaurant in the foyer and I used it for a good meal at a reasonable price several times. There is a laundry service and a washing machine in the public bath. The public bath was a cultural experience and very enjoyable with the steaming hot pool. Very happy with this hotel, it's position, it's amenities and the price.

The hotel location is excellent: while being quiet residential area it's just a walking distance to many attraction including kabuki theater, Tokyo Tower and fish market. Under 10 min from the train by walk. 15 min by taxi to Tokyo station should you need a bullet train or just any train to move around the country. Rooms are fair size, super clean. Plenty of toiletries and they give you pretty PJs every day so pack light. There is an onset (a spa) on the last floor which we used every day. Stuff is very friendly and speak English. Restaurant downstars is ok for convenience but we only used it for coffee/tea- any eatery in Japan is good so we wanted to explore as much as possible. Would absolutely recommend this hotel- best price in the area for what you get.
