review_body: This is a nice comfortable hotel. The rooms are clean and of a good size. The bathroom is OK. The beds are comfortable. The breakfast in the morning is OK. The location is in a quiet neighbourhood not far from a JR station

The hotel is near the hamamatsucho monorail thus acces is quite easy from Hareda airport, though the area it is in is rather drab. Most things to see are some distance away. Service was okay, the room was in good condition though rather unattractive. The room size is about 20sqm which is good for Tokyo. The air cond worked well though bed was rather low and too soft. Breakfast okay though uninspiring. I would recommend it if price is good, not if the full tariff is charged.

Mitsui Garden is usually a dependable Japanese hotel chain, but this branch in the Shiodome neighborhood is a glaring exception to the rule. Front desk is basically staffed by non-English-speaking trainees who know very little --if anything at all-- about their jobs and the hotel itself. The only person in the staff who really speaks English --a lovely girl raised in Canada-- is not in everyday.I'm still here, at the moment facing the following problems:--Noisy room facing the subway tracks (I had asked for a silent room in my reservation, to no avail);--Telephone does not work;--Exhaust vent in the bathroom extremely noisy, can't turn it off;--A/C has no temperature control, you have to choose between on or off and that's it;--No help with restaurant reservations, because nobody at front desk speaks English well enough to understand what the guests are asking.I just went down to front desk to ask for a possible room change. But gave up after a 40-minute teeth-cringing study in miscommunication. The trainee who tried to help me spoke almost no English. When I asked to see a manager, I found out that said manager has zero English skills. I just gave up.The Mitsui Garden Shiodome is a 4-star hotel that charges 4-star rates, but offers ridiculously amateurish services. Will never stay here again, and encourage all non-Japanese-speakers who are reading this review to do the same.This is my 6th visit to Japan, a country that I love. But I don't love Mitsui Garden Shiodome, that much I can say.

I checked in quite late and unfortunately they did not have a non smoking room available. Although they put some air freshening aerosol in the room the smoking rooms are really bad. So make sure you book a non smoking room. The gentleman at reception told me that they don't have any non smoking rooms available for the duraration of my stay. The next morning I dropped in at reception and a lady helped me she said there are non smoking rooms available and offered to me my belongings during the day. The same gentleman from the previous night asked her what the problem is and dissapeared. I got my non smoking room. The rooms are comfortable with free wi-fi. Breakfast was included in my deal but it was so poor and with really strange choices that I skipped it. The hotel is within walking distance (20 minutes) from the station and resturants.

Stayed one night and arrived late. Booked a double room which was spacious for one person. Bed comfortable and room clean. Reception staff was very friendly and spoke English well. A welcome email is sent before arrival, which enables one to check details again.The onsen is quite relaxing after a long day. Breakfast was excellent with a variation of dishes and fresh fruit.The hotel is close to the monorail which makes for a smooth and efficient trip to Haneda airport.Would stay here again.

Ok so what do you want to hear from a review?The room was a superior room and spacious for 2 people (more than most Tokyo hotels i hear)Room was really clean everyday and the hotel staff were really accommodating. In terms of location: we wanted to use the subway to get around Tokyo and Diamon station is a 5/10 minute walk away so really ideal for us. If you fly to Narita or Haneda you can get the subway to Diamon and it will be no more than ¥1300. Per person which is considerably cheaper than ANY other method. And all the subways have escalators so no bother for luggage. Can't moan at all with anything this hotel had to offer. Great stuff (first time visitors to Japan)

The hotel is located near the subway, restaurants, cafes, and the WTC. The rooms are good and there is the traditional japoneses bath. And you can wear kimono inside the hotel. The breakfast you can find japoneses and ocidental foods.

This hotel is either newly constructed or recently renovated. Two friends and I stayed in a well furnished room with 3 single beds. Compared to hotels in other cities in Japan, the room was reasonably spacious. I didn't go to the spa, but the hotel offers two spa areas, one for males and the other for females. Also, I didn't clock the distance from the hotel to the nearest subway or JR Station, but it seemed to be about 1/3rd of a mile (or 0.5 km). If you don't speak Japanese, but are fluent or proficient in English, language barriers should not be an issue. The employee who handled our check-in spoke fluent English. The other employees with whom I interacted didn't appear to speak fluent English, but certainly spoke English well enough to help me. If you're from a primarily English speaking nation, I realize that you may desire a hotel at which all employees speak fluent English. However, the employees of this hotel were the most fluent or proficient compared to the other 5 hotels at which we stayed in Japan, with the exception of one hotel that is specifically geared towards U.S.A. residents. The hotel is located in what appears to be a relative new or revitalized area, and contains European style buildings. It felt very nice and safe. Among other restaurants, there was a reasonably-priced curry restaurant nearby. There was also a Lawson Natural store, which I'm guessing is an upscale brand of Lawson convenience stores. Nightlife is somewhat non-existent around this hotel. However, I was OK with that. If you want nightlife, you can easily take transit to another area of the city, such as Rippongi, then come back to the hotel for sleep. I will note that taxi, whether it be Uber or a regular city cab, may be your best option after 12:00AM-ish, as many forms of transit shut down around then.

Room is average size which fits nicely for 2 pax. There's direct monorail to/from Haneda airport which we took. Only 20 mins ride. There is metro and JR line which are 6 min walking distance. It is not far, however, when it rained (which it did at night in my trip), the walk felt tremendously far. Hotel room is spotless clean. Great to come back to a nice room after a tiring day. There's Lawson mini mart 1 min walk away from hotel. You won't get the hustle and bustle of city here. I was looking for midnight supper but was told there's nothing in vicinity. It was 11pm.I'll suggest this place for comfort and convenience. But not so much on night life.

Stayed here during our trip to Japan! A few minutes walk away from Tokyo Tower and other tourist areas. Calm atmosphere and great service. Close to Daimon train station. Was very quiet even with a construction site next to it.

This is kind of big hotel in Shiodome area. Me and my friends have one night stay here, checked in late night and the staffs still took good care of us. Our tripple room is ok size compare to other hotels in Tokyo. It's clean and comfy. Also we enjoy the onsen on the top floor that was so relax and comfortable. Only 10-steps walk to one big Lawson minimart downstair was convenient. At night the area is silent with nobody. Just a little bit too far from the station, walking about 10 minutes with huge luggages could be tired.

We were delighted with this hotel when we first visited in 2010 and I am pleased to say that the high standards have been maintained and that the hotel still provides clean, modern and well-appointed accommodation. For us, travelling on a JR Rail Pass, this hotel could not be better placed: 5 mins from the train station, we did not have to use the subway once. This was a great saving in money and time! The hotel is still very good value for Tokyo and the rooms have been modernised since our last visit. Space was NOT a problem and we made full use of the hotel public baths/onsen. Breakfast is worth trying too: plenty of choice and good quality. I would thoroughly recommend this hotel.

We stayed two nights twice during our Japan trip. Good hotel, small rooms (bed in a corner) but functional. Friendly staff. Public bath. Breakfast buffet ok. Close to station and monorail to Haneda airport, which is very handy. Close to a number of restaurants, which are a good alternative to the hotel's buffet restaurant.

This turned out to be a great choice for my first trip to Tokyo. Staff was excellent, most spoke English, room was sparkling clean, breakfast buffet was good, no complaints. I was particularly impressed when I needed to change rooms to stay an extra day and they made it happen, moved my luggage to the new room, no muss no fuss. Hotel is in a quiet Tokyo neighborhood and I would stay there again. Note it is a short walk to Hamamatsucho R Rail station so it is easy to get around Tokyo as the Yamanote line circles the city.

Check in and out was swift, love the nespresso machine in the room as I need that caffeine kick before starting my day exploring Tokyo. the onsen is good too after tiring day walking around tokyo, the staff speaks fluent english which is a good to ask for directions and sightseeing info. The area is a bit quite at night, it's about 10-15 minutes walk to Ginza and 10 minutes to Tokyo Tower. We also stayed at the top floor so we could see very clearly Tokyo Tower from our window. Overall, it's a nice hotel and we will highly recommend it to our friends and family.

Awesome hotel very friendly helpful staff. Close to jr rail station hamamatsucho about a 8 minute walk. Lots of small restaurants in the area walkable to tokyo tower about 20 minutes. Close to monorail for hananeda airport. We flew into narita. The narita express stops at shinagawa then hop on yamote line to hamamatsucho about 2 stops. Would highly recommend. Husband enjoyed the onsen.

Stayed here for my one-night layover from America to Asia. Was debating between this one and another small business hotel that has just opened near Tokyo Station. Public bath was a game changer. It's rather rare for a downtown hotel to have public bath. Despite its smaller size, I still enjoyed it a lot (good to soak up in hot bath after long journey).Staff were friendly and speak fairly good English. And the hotel is next to Daimon Station, which is surprisingly convenient to many points of interests (eg. Tokyo Tower, Roppongi, etc.) on Metro Ōedo Line. It's also close to Hamamatsuchō station on Tokyo Monorail for easy access to Haneda Airport. Overall a great stay.Ps. Room came with free/complimentary water. A really good amenity compared to global chains where you might get those only if you have status.

Clean, comfortable and cozy hotel with basic amenities. It's close to public transport and situated near central Yamanote line. Yamanote line is what you will need to access most of the tourist spots like Shibuya, Shinjuku, harajuku, yoyogi park etc

Traditional hotel with all the necessary accessories. Within walking distance (approx. 10-15 min) to the train station. Nothing exciting but an acceptable location as base for sightseeing Tokyo. One advantage is that the local area for street food with multiple restaurants – don’t miss out on this!

This is the second time we have stayed here. Both times staff have been friendly and helpful.Rooms are a good size for Tokyo, and well equipped,with tea and coffee available as well as a safe.It is located fairly close to Hamamatsucho station which great if flying using Haneda, just take monorail from airport.We will use this hotel again.

This was my first hotel in Japan. I walked there from Hamamatsucho station where my train from Haneda airport arrived, so very convenient. In the next days I walked to the fish market, Ginza and the Imperial gardens and Hama Rikyu garden from there, so for me it was a good location. There are a lot of eating and drinking pleaces on the other side of the railway track by another station (Shimbashi I think).Check in was swift and professional. On my desk there was a message saying that there will be building noise outside in the morning. I was not impressed, especially as I was reading this at my late arrival at 1.30 am. Then in the morning at 7.45 a look out of my window gave me the 1st "wow, Japan" moment: The buiders were lined up for morning gymnastics!The room was clean and comfortable. The pillows were odd, there seemed to be beads in them, but they are the same now in my next hotel. There is a charger provided with all sorts of connections. I used for my phone and it worked ok. Now in the next hotel there is the same charger and it says that it can erase the memory of the phone? Not sure that was a real risk. I was also provided with an adapter for my other British plugs.The choice of breakfast was good - for Japanese people. I struggled to find stuff I actually wanted to eat. There were some mysteries such as "eggslut". When I asked what that is the answer was "eggslut" again.The day I left it rained and I asked at reception for a taxi. They told me as it was raining that would be difficult and I should take the train. It wasn't rush hour, so not sure why they were not keen, but I didn't feel sytongly enough about it to argue. Otherwise the checkout was easy.I tried the onsen thing. Not for me. Give it a shot though as it is free.

This was a pleasant enough place. Luckily we were upgraded for free to a bigger room though it did overlook a building site. They did warn us there may be noise during the day but actually it wasn't too bad as we were out most of the time. The staff were nice but seemed a bit clueless about the local area. The Italian buffet restaurant attached to the hotel didn't look great. The location felt a little remote. It was about 10minute walk through an area with Italian restaurants to the nearest station. I did get very confused when trying to walk back from another station as my google map took me to the another Mitsui Garden hotel so I had to walk in the opposite direction back to find the hotel. There were some Japanese restaurant areas about another 10minutes away which were very good. There is also a park and lovely Japanese gardens nearby.

Convenient location near subway station and train to the airport. Rooms are large at Tokyo standard. Amenities are decent for a business trip. Staff were competent and attentive - polite as Japanese usually are but not going out of their way to help. The major benefit of the hotel is its value. For the same price one can hardly find a better option with the same convenient location and room amenities.
