review_body: Nice hotel in a relatively convenient location, assuming you are on a business trip. On the contrary, as a tourist you might want to look somewhere else as position is not very convenient to major attractions or access to public transportation.Room was ok. What we found disappointing was the poor quality of breakfast and the fact that, after spending 5 nights in this hotel, we have been charged ¥ 1'000 per hour when we requested a late check-out because of an emergency that we had on the last day of our stay which prevented us from leaving the room at 11.00am. We asked for one hour late check-out and we have been asked to pay ¥ 1'000. What we found even more disturbing is the very little amount that we have been asked to pay extra for a service that any of the other hundreds of hotels we stayed in our life offered for free (especially when the delay was limited to very few hours, as in this case). This sounded very much as a statement of the poor focus of this hotel on the customer.Or at least this is the way we perceived it. In fact, we'll make sure not to return to this hotel ever again. Tokyo is full of good hotels after all, especially in this price range.

I have stayed here a few times now. It is a good hotel, quite convenient for Hamamatsucho station (monorail to Haneda) and Shimbashi, with plenty of restaurants and good ramen shops. Rooms are a good size and beds are comfortable. In room Wi-Fi is a little flakey sometimes, but the wired internet works OK with the pocket adapter I always carry with me in Japan. The restaurant is good value for lunch but a little pricey for breakfast (?!) but there is a convenience store nearby and the smokiest Pronto coffee shop that I have been too!Hotel has an Onsen on the top floor, it is OK, but not fantastic. There is some building work going on nearby but it was not too invasive.

Stayed here with my family just a week ago and it was lovely. The hotel is located in a very quiet area yet it is only a few minutes walk to Shinbashi (approx. 10mins) and 20 minutes walk to Ginza. The Tsukiji Fish market is only a few subway station away or you can always walk (approx. 20mins). So if you don't mind walking, this hotel would be a great choice! The rooms are spacious in Tokyo standards with lots of floor space, I could easily have two 30inches suitcases opened at the same time on the floor. The bonus of staying at this hotel is that guests can enjoy the use of the public bath on 13th floor which I did everyday as it really helps to relief the muscle fatigue you have accumulated. Just a friendly reminder that in Japan, you must wash yourself before you take a dip in the bath. Overall it was a great stay, very clean rooms, helpful staff, and I would definitely come again!

Stayed here last week and we enjoyed our stay. Price was really good; room is bigger than average hotels in Japan.I really loved the vending machines on every floor and onsen (free to use); best way to relax after a tiring day walking around Tokyo. Lovely staff! One staff spent almost an hour helping me with printing my disney tix (most annoying file ever). Thank you very much for helping me! Even though its close to train lines, it was not noisy at all. Trains were walking distance (15mins) but we took a taxi most of the time since there was 3 of us. It only costed ¥730 to get to Hamamatsucho station from the hotel. This line takes you to the popular areas - Shibuya/Akihabara/etcHighly recommend and I'll defs come back!

Hotel location is nice though some walking distance from nearest subway. Not much interaction with the staff and check in process is smooth.There are lot of different restaurant nearby which you can explore at night.Room is well equipped though not spacious. It does provide multi charge adapter for smart phone (Apple or Android smart phone).Pleasant stay overall.

About 7 to 10 minutes walk from JR Hamamatsucho station. Very decent and clean room. Awesome housekeeping! However, the room that we stayed in, was not suitable for 3 person stay because with the extra bed, there was no space to room about and nowhere to lay down our luggage.The front desk staff who checked us in, was not helpful though. We were heading out of the hotel after check in because the room was not ready. When we asked if our luggage would be sent to the room when it is ready because we would be back late at night to collect the room keys, the staff replied maybe. What is the meaning of "maybe"? Maybe the hotel would send the luggage up when the room is ready? Maybe we have to carry our own luggage up to the room when we return at night to collect the room keys? Maybe there is a luggage service? I do not understand. Utterly disappointed. This is a business hotel and ultimately, they may not even take my feedback because I am not there for business. But still, this is disappointing. Anyway, I will not go back to stay again, and I will not recommend to my family and friends. Thank you.

The hotel is very nice, the reception staff were very friendly and helpful, giving us direction and all. The surroundings of the hotel were full of restaurants and family marts, and a walking distance to many places, like the WTC Hamamatsucho Terminal.

Our stay was very relaxing, we had so much fun. The room was not that big, but it was a welcome sight for me and my wife after a hectic trip around Tokyo, like the Tokyo Tower, Caretta Shiodome and lots more, we will definitely come back and stay again at the Mitsui Garden Hotel Shiodome.

I stayed here for work so it really served its purpose, nothing more than l needed.Room is small but as expected, but it is essentially all the equipment for what you need, including the crowded morning breakfast rush. Chose this because of its proximity to the metro line l needed, at first it is a bit fiddly there isn't much happening around it, though enough restaurants to keep you busy eating until late. the only thing l will remember from it will be the robotic standard courtesy of staff, good for the rest of the world, a little short for japan. bed is (asian) hard.just unmemorable. a tad pricey for what it offered, but will do its job if you need a sleep and go.

Tokyo is huge. If planning to stay near Haneda Airport, I would consider this hotel. It is listed as a 3 star business hotel.The downside is it is located between two train stations, Shimbashi JR/Shiodome metro and Hamamatsucho JR/Tokyo monorail/Daimon metro, so walking 400-600 metres with luggage is a must. In good weather, it is fine but the road is cobbled so watch the luggage. If coming out from Hamamatsucho, take the North exit and walk across the traffic junction. There is a Lawson on the left and the train track on the right. There is a small road between the two. walking 350 metres along, you will see the hotel on the left. From Shimbashi, walk south with the train tracks to your left.The hotel rooms are upgraded. stayed 3 nights and another later in the itinerary. The triple room is small because of the third bed. Took a small queen double on the last night. It is spacious because of the layout, easily fitting 3 big luggage.Check-in was smooth and a 4x4 metres public bath was very nice.comments about central ventilation are true so I just switched on the ioniser and off the central heating. It is walking distance to Tsukiji market (20 mins), Ginza(20 mins), Tokyo Tower (30 mins) through the cemetery.

Nice, comfortable and clean room. Well priced. Good and very reasonable price breakfast. Staff willing to help.The down side is its location: a bit of walking distance from train stations and not really at the center of everything.One thing I don't understand is the hotel's air-conditioning system: only the central heater was turned on at the time and you can't really "adjust" the temperature but to turn it off completely because it was too hot. With the air-conditioner turned off, window has to be opened: mosquitoes and noise came.Don't know if it was Japanese way of doing things but hotel could be a bit more flexible with check in time: arrived at 6:30 am after a long flight and had to seat on a chair to wait until 3:00pm for a room while it's pouring down outside is not very enjoyable.

- room is clean- staff is helpful- place is comfortable- bed is clean- bathroom stuff are ok- heater is enough to warm the room against the cold temperature outside- place is near the Daimon station or Hamamatsucho train- there are a lot of restaurants nearby. Lots of Lawson, 711 and other groceries too- neighborhood is quiet* wish they would allow others to check-in earlier without charge. I supposed there are other guests who checks out earlier than 11am

Hotel OK .... Had to stay in smoking room as nothing else available over 8 nights! Book early for non - smoking!! Restaurant was also OK... Other nice restaurants near by.Railway/subway a 5-8 minute walk

I love the Mitsui Garden chain, it's reasonably priced, rooms are of a decent size (for Japan) and very well kept, with a great internet access and amenities. The hotes normally have a "Daiyokujyou", or public bath, which is a great way to relieve stress accumulated during the day. Price is norally very reasonable too, which is a great point to consider of course! Totally recommended!

The Mitsui garden Itali-Gia is a nice hotel in a very good and quite neighborhood. There is a subway station and JR line nearby (Daimon and Hamamatsucho) 7-10 min walk. It's nearby shimbashi station and walkable from Ginza neighborhood. Clean rooms, friendly staff.

Decent hotel with mostly business visitors. Not suitable for families since rooms are a bit small. Very clean with all facilities and extras. There's a hot bath on the top floor and a washing machine to do your own laundry. The neighborhood has a lot of nice restaurants and bars, and you're close to the Ginzo shopping district. Breakfast is over priced, and mainly catered towered Japanese taste (miso soup, fish, pickles, etc).

I stayed at this hotel for the first time. As one of the Mitsui Garden Hotels you get the similar quality of the service and room facility. Breakfast buffet offers good value as well. What I, however, have to mention is the location: a bit far from the surrounding underground/JR stations, and difficult to find.

We recently stayed in a semi-double room, which had one full-size bed (smaller than a queen but larger than a twin). The room and bed were large enough for us (2 adults with minimal luggage) but may be small for others. The onsen was small compared to other hotels we've stayed at, but adequate. We walked from the Hamamatsucho Station by taking the North Exit. There is a small street/alley directly across from the north exit. The tracks are on your right and buildings on your left. The hotel is 7 blocks from the station.The lunch buffet was nice and decently priced at 14,000 yen per person.

This hotel is just right for a simple stay. Not too big, not too small, food is good, and the area is quite. Not too far from anything neither. If you want to go out for the night and find something to eat, Ginza is just a couple blocks away. Staff is friendly and can speak English well. Also, if you get a room with its own shower, don't be alarmed if you get a slip about the public showers. It's only optional. The rooms are very clean as well. I highly recommend it for anyone who wants an affordable, comfortable, and not over-the-top hotel.

Our first full day Sumo adventure awaited, and not wanting to miss a moment of the action, we came up to Tokyo from Nagoya the Friday night before and stayed 2 nights. The hotel is near Hamamatsucho Station, Daimon Station - giving great access to other parts of Tokyo. Check in was seamless, the staff at the front desk welcoming. Our room was nicely appointed, clean and the wifi very good. So good we could stream the Rugby, an imperative over the course of the weekend!We didn't try the restaurant or the public baths so are unable to comment. There is a huge construction site across the road on one side (the side our room was on), though this didn't impact us noise wise - the room is well insulated. I wonder though what will happen when the huge new Fire Station, along the other side of the hotel, goes into service ...

My family and I stayed at the hotel for a week in September. The hotel is only 5min walk from the hamamatsucho train station and has many small restaurants and cafes in the area. There are two Lawson convenience stores close by, and a larger supermarket 2 mins walk away. The hotel was very clean and the room was spacious for Tokyo standards. I loved the Japanese robes and slippers in the rooms, a nice traditional touch. The rooms were serviced every day and included free bottled water. There is also a lovely communal bath on the 13th floor. I didn't use it myself, however my mother loved it, found it very soothing and relaxing.** The communal bath is nude, this is no real problem, all guests are very polite however no swimwear is permitted. The hotel has a lovely buffet on the 1st floor that has a great selection of both Japanese and western food. The buffet was always busy and very reasonably priced. Lastly and most importantly Staff at the hotel were exceptional! They went out of their way to help and assist, nothing was too much trouble. Thank-you to all the front desk Staff, we really appreciated all your help with restaurants and directions. Overall a great hotel, stay here for close access for the hama rikyu tea gardens and Ginza shopping.

The location was fine, a little bit of distance from Tokyo Tower, Ginza, and the Fish Market, but all were walkable. The hotel was comfortable and the staff was helpful. Although a touch pricey, I did enjoy the hotel breakfast. If I stayed in this neighborhood again I would definitely return.

i stayed in this hotel during my first trip to tokyo. Location of the hotel is just walk able to subway station. service was really excellent. room was quite small but equipped with all facilities. i stayed there for 4 days.Since i am vegetarian i didnt get chance to try the restaurant . You will hear the noise of trains passing by which cant be avoided. tokyo fish market is walkable from here.

Hotel is situated well, close to metro but the room was a little tight for 3 people with the two double beds taking up 80% of the room.The traditional hot spa on the top floor was very nice to relax in at the end of the day. Not a bad price for a central hotel in a very nice neighbourhood.

Overall we found the hotel came in ok quality for the money we paid (ca. $90 per night without meals via online booking). The location of this hotel is not that great. You need to walk with your baggage about 10min or so with your baggage from any of the train nearby stations. A bit of disappointment with the room was the cleanness of the bathroom. It gave a bit moldy smell and that made out bath time not completely happy. This hotel has a large "public" bath known as Onsen style bathing room on its highest floor of 13th. Obviously, you are not supported to wear any thing with you when bathing. But why not! It might make your visit a unique one! We could comeback to this hotel if there is no other food choice in Tokyo. But we have not strong reason to do so other than availability of other reasonable hotels.

this is a clean budget hotel near ginza, the area of the hotel is very nice with several restaurants and cafe's in the area, however it is quite a walk from the near by station, it will take your around 10 minutes to get to it, the hotel is clean and staff are friendly, however there is a major issue in the hotel which is Air conditioning, all rooms have there own units and they work just fine however the hotel management dont allow you to set your own temperature when i was staying there it was a little cold outside so they set the hotel to heat you cannot set your A/C to cool the only option you have is to turn it off, the temperature inside the room was around 25 degrees with the AC was off, which was a bit hot for me specially you couldn't open the window "only two inches" i had to change to a different hotel because of that, other than that it is a very busy hotel with lots of guests coming in and out wich might be a problem for some...
user_name:
Abdulaziz A
Al Khobar, Saudi Arabia

review_body: Clean, comfortable and peaceful. A little off the main street which suited us in terms of noise/traffic. Really close to a central train station making commuting to other places really easy. Staff are professional and friendly and very accommodating in terms of speaking English/phoning taxis and so on. Very good value for money.Wifi a little dodgy but possibly due to the floor we were on.

We stayed for 7 nights. The standard double room was spacious, enough space for our two suitcases. Enjoyed the in-room complimentary drip coffee. Room was carefully cleaned daily. Front desk was helpful and accommodating. The staff recommended a nearby yakiniku (Niku Man) restaurant that gave us a very enjoyable evening. There are also many cozy soba/udon eateries within walking distance. Will definitely stay here again.

I feel this is a budget hotel, it's ok but not great. Rooms are clean but small, beds not very confortable. There is a small restaurant by the reception where you can have breakfast. The hotel is in a quiet area, and there is absolutely nothing of interest nearby. You can walk 5 min to the nearest station where you find some restaurants. 15 min walk to Tokyo Tower. We stayed only one night, next time we will try to find a different hotel.

Very Noisy , clean , all beds no space for luggage , small bed room , small bathroom , long check in , the food was a little good. 10 min. walk to the train Station. Little far for the train Station. Good view , it smelled bad. This cannot be for 45 years old and above. If your 45 and above you will not appreciate it. Our luggage was delivered after 30 or 45 mins, I don't know why! You get what you pay for.

Traveling on business, this hotel felt like a cozy apartment to me. Comfortable-enough bed, desk area (with bookshelf and decoratives near), small fridge with complimentary water, hot water kettle and teas, and nice modern bathroom. Elaborate breakfasts included traditional and European/American fare. A convenience store around the corner was great for water and workday snacks.

in fact it is only 8 minutes walk from monorail terminal, JR station and metro if you know the way. it is quiet, comfortable and the area is quite unique in the busy tokyo business district.The surrounding has its unique european small town feel. Personally I enjoy staying there.

Hotel was great. Peaceful community and very accessible to taxis. A couple of minutes away from Hamamatsucho station. Also very close to Ginza. Front desk wAs very helpful and they try their very best to assist you even if they dont speak fluent english. Breakfast was basic and it served both italian and japanese. In other days, we ate breakfast at this small authentic japanese restaurant just across the street thats open around 7am. Also, Lawson (convenient store) is just at the next building. Would check in here again.

We visited during Hanami (Cherry Blossom) viewing season so accommodation was EXTREMELY (ridiculously) expensive Tokyo wide. We ended up booking through a Japanese website as other (Non Japanese) online sites were overly expensive. We stayed at the Mitsui Garden Shiodome Italia-Gai hotel which is within walking distance (5mins) of Hamamastu-Cho Station which has a direct monorail line to Haneda Airport. Close to Ginza and Tokyo station and on the Yamanote JR line that circles Tokyo, giving you easy access to the likes of Shibuya, Harajuku and Shinkjuku.The hotel itself was new and in a safe and quiet neighbourhood. Reception staff were friendly and spoke good English. Rooms were 20m² which for Japanese standards and for the price was not too bad. There were plenty of much much smaller rooms on offer on other sited for 2 or 3 times the price.We didn't use the restaurant in the hotel but it was an Italian Restaurant (matching the feeling of the surrounding area) that had Breakfast and then offered an all you could eat buffet for lunch and dinner for a decent price. The communal bath house on the top floor is an absolute winner!!!!Free Wi-fi in the rooms however service was sporadic.Great location and a nice clean hotel. Would stay there again.

The location is just midway of JR/metro stations which means 10+ mins walking distance in either way. It is hard to say it remote and inconvenience but there are hotels at better locations of similar room rate. The room itself is very good allowing reasonable space for us. It is equipped with both in-room free wi-fi and wired Internet.

This is a fairly standard three star Japanese business hotel, which means it will be comfortable and clean but with few amenities. The front desk staff were not particularly helpful with providing directions or answering questions. The breakfast was kinda weird. Not Japanese, not western, just a bizarre fusion of both. This hotel was saved by its wonderful public bath facility on the top floor( not exactly standard for business hotels in Tokyo. It relieved my jet lag daily during my stay, and was a much looked foward to part of every evening

Not far from train station by walking distance. It’s around 15mins from train station to the hotel by walking. Surrounding with restaurant, convenient shops, drug stores. Easy to access attracting point in Tokyo by train (Near Tokyo bay and Tokyo tower). The room is clean with free wifi and other equipment’s. in the night the area is quiet and easy to get sleeping well.

This is a standard 3-star hotel. The lobby and breakfast area are small, and the rooms are tiny and pretty basic.We stayed here, due to last minute travel plans. The location, though not too far from the metro station and JR stations (8-10 min walk), is not entirely ideal as the hotel is located in a very quiet back street, filled with small offices and a few restaurants. There isn't much to do or see within that area. We thought the check-in process was very slow, until our check-out experience! I am not sure of the payment mode my husband used (maybe it was prepared by his company), but the front-desk did not give us a payment receipt upon checking out. My husband asked for a bill print-out. The front desk staff struggled with the request for almost 10 min. We got tired of waiting and told her to just forget about it, as we were in a hurry to catch a train. She then asked her colleague for help, which he did so, effortlessly. I supposed she must have been a new staff, but I can't understand why she can be so poorly trained. Isn't bill printing a pretty standard process for front-desk staff to handle?During one of the days, we asked for direction to Chidorigafuchi, and to my surprised, the staff (a different staff) took quite a long while (maybe 10 min or so) to do his research and give us the information. Chidorigafuchi happens to be among the top 3 sakura viewing spots in Tokyo during spring season, and we were there during the peak of the sakura season. I had expected him (the hotel) to have such information at his fingertips. Another issue I had with the hotel is their pillows - ie. the traditional Japanese pillow (I think it was filled with buckwheat). Maybe this doesn't bother other hotel guests but I found it to be extremely small, hard and uncomfortable. As a result I slept very poorly throughout my 2 nights stay there. I did not ask the hotel if they provide western styled pillow.

Our stay was one of those rare occasions where a hotel scores top marks in every category. We liked everything - the location for transport, shopping and culture (three train stations in easy walking distance - 10-15 min), Tokyo Tower/Zojoji temple, Hamarikyu Gardens and Ginza also nearby.- very good restaurant with generous buffet - exceptionally friendly and attentative staff. And all at prices which can be called moderate by Tokyo standards.It must be said that the internet (wi-fi) was a bit slow in the evenings when everybody was checking their mail and skyping home/watching online TV - no foreign language TV channels. (Internet was fine at other times of the day.).We had a generous double room (by Tokyo standards) and there were even adapters for I-Phones etc. Generally a very quiet location but the rooms facing towards the railway line would have some noise with open windows.Nice neighbourhood with small Italian-style restaurants.

The Mitsui Garden Hotel Shiodome Italian-gai is easy to get to from both NRT and HND airports. Take the Keisei Sky Liner from NRT to the Daimon stop or the monorail from HND to the Hamamatsucho stop. Walk five minutes to the hotel. Renting global wifi at the airport was great. It was under $10 per day and kept us connected everywhere, even in the metro. It really helped us navigate the city. The hotel is new, clean and modern. Quiet rooms and comfortable beds. There is currently construction going on across the street, but we were out all day and didn't hear anything when in the room. Nice toiletries provided. Mini fridge in each room and complimentary bottled water each day. We ate in the restaurant the first day. Huge buffet was good, but preferred a smaller breakfast the following days at the nearby Pronto Cafe. The staff was very helpful in providing directions and maps. Our only complaint was that we couldn't get cooling in our room. We turned off the heat and opened the window for air. The Hamarikyu Garden is a five minute walk and the Tsukiji Fish Market is ten min. past the garden. The Shimbashi area has lots of great restaurants for dinner, tiny places, narrow alleys, a true local experience. The two main metro stations that we used were Daimon and Shimbashi. If you don't mind walking 5 minutes to metro and restaurants, the hotel is fine. I would stay at this property again.

Nice hotel in a nice neighbourhood! 5 minutes walk to subway station. Close to train station which takes you to Tokyo Big Sight exhibition. Rooms were clean and nice. If i need to find something bad it should be the view from the room, the window was facing a wall on the next building. Will stay here again!

The location of this hotel was perfect: 10 minutes north of Daimon Station, 10 minutes East of Onarimon Station and 7 minutes south of Shiodome/Shimbashi Station. It has the Lawson convenience store next to it, the Hamarikyu Gardens 5 minutes away and small eateries surrounding the hotel. The price was reasonable for a 3.5-4 star hotel, with a medium sized room, a sento bath on the top floor, free chargers and free wifi. I will stay there again next time.

Very impressive when reached the hotel room. It was spacious especially we have 3 pax in a room and the room was clean and neat . The location maybe slightly far but with the space we get for the room - worth the extra few minutes walk!Only set back is the sound proof maybe be as good ppl walking at the walkway you be able to hear the noise but that's the individual behaviors of the customer .

The hotel is located close to the JR lines stations (Hamamatsucho) and some places of interests are in walking distance (Sengaku-ji Temple, Tokyo TV Tower, Rainbow Bridge) or on JR lines (Shibuya). We haven't booked breakfast, but the rooms were spacious enough with all the necessary equippment. The room has even a office table and the electricity convertor for Japanese plug is available. There is also water cooker and free tea, coffee and bottles of water available every day. The free wi-fi internet works, but the connection was quit slow.

I agree with previous review that considering hotel is in Tokyo, the front desk staff struggled with English & were not as friendly. However, it was a nice hotel in a quiet neighborhood. For future travellers: the closest train station is Hamamatsucho, not Shimbashi. Also loved that guests have access to public bath. A must try although I would have wished to have experienced onsen at a hot spring.

I suppose this was a decent hotel for the money however much improvement is needed before it can be considered a 4 star business hotel. First off the staff struggles with English, I'm aware it is not their first language but almost all business hotels in the area have someone that speaks English. This made checking in difficult and when I had laundry done it came back exactly how I asked it not to. Second, the internet is HORRIBLE. If you think you're going to get back to the room and finish up e-mails it's not going to happen. The bandwidth speed is 0 between 5-10PM. I could not even open up Google.com in under 5 minutes. Third, the food at the "restaurant" is horrible, last nights dinner left overs is tomorrows breakfast. The hotel lobby always smells like old oregano. Fourth, the pillows are like cinder blocks, one side is full of glass marbles, the other side, concrete. Now the few pros, the house keeping staff is awesome. They are very quick, do a great job, and are trust worthy. I accidentally forgot to lock my watches in the safe one day and they were right on the desk when I got back. Someone mentioned noise. I slept with both the windows opened and closed, while I did notice the JR line with the window open, I had no trouble sleeping. There isn't a whole lot of places to eat right around the hotel but if you walk towards the metro stop you can find plenty of places.

Overall hotel is ok - clean, tidy rooms, amenities, etc. My biggest problem with this hotel is the noise leaking in from the windows. You can hear the trains arriving, noise on roads, cars on motorway, construction workers, sirens late at night, etc. It's as if the window is open. They have tried to resolve this by using double padding curtains. Also you can hear the people in the rooms eg above you or next to you. To add to this we had the fire alarm wake us up at 1am and we were told to wait in our room and then told to go back to sleep. So if your not fussed with noise then this place is fine. Location is average too. Definitively not central like shibuya and not full with shops and restaurants like Odaiba. Only thing near by is Lawson's and the downstairs italian place.

Nice room, and surprisingly quite big for Japanese standard. We had enough place for our luggage, the is a convenient store just under it. Wi-Fi in the room. Very easy to find, walking distance to the Hamamatcucho train station, and the Diamon metro station. We rented for New Year eve so the price was very high , but we could walk to the Zojoji Temple and the Tokyo Tower.

We stayed here on New Years Eve for 3 nights. It's was very quiet - which I liked! Very close to Hamatsucho station - great for taking the monorail from Haneda. You could easily walk from the station to the hotel if you don't have super heavy luggage. Rooms are small but by Japanese standards quite good, staff is nice - most spoke some English. Didn't try the restaurant but it was busy so I assume it was ok. Would stay here again.

Good value hotel. Hotel room is rather huge for Japan standard. Conveniently located near hamamatsucho and daimon stations which gets to to almost everywhere in Tokyo. Checked into the hotel at 9pm. Had to wait in a long queue for check in. Looks like a tour group hotel. Forwarded my bags to the hotel a day before and it got there in perfect condition. Convenience shop just on the right of the hotel.

This is a very nice hotel in amazing location with very good access to public transport.Rooms are beautifull and for Tokyo standards have a good size. The staff is very helpfull and the food is good. There are plenty of restaurnats around also!We liked very much the setting of the room and the bed. Internet is also very good and accessible from all the hotel. The room had also a multi-charger for mobile phones and pads.

Well located hotel with well thought out room plans and a little more space than one is generally used to in Japan when staying at comparable hotels. The rooms were also clean and comfortable.Clean and a good sized full bathrooms with amenities.Italian restaurant in the lobby has good food and also is where you eat breakfast with good international selections as well as local tastes.Would benefit from having some (or even 1!) international TV channel as there is nothing except for local Japanese TV so not very internationally friendly for a long stay.There was a public bath within the hotel but i didn't use it.

Location is a must for money value: walking distance to Ginza, close to the Tokyo Metro at Shimbashi Station as well as JR lines (Simbashi and Hamamatsucho stations). Breakfast buffet is complete, with Japanese and Western food. The 13th floor public bath is relaxing, open until 1AM. Exchange money machine is helpful in the absence of an ATM.The surroundings are interesting, a quite zone with stone paved roads, good fancy small restaurants.

Good location because simple to get to from the airport and easy enough to walk to Ginza area, although it may feel a little bit 'away' when compared with Mitsui Ginza Premier. It has a feel of a coach or package deal hotel - like the ones you get put up in if your flight is delayed. We didn't breakfast here, but it did look manically busy. It is a good enough hotel, functional and was fine for a first night in Tokyo when you are just getting your bearings.

The room was clean, sufficient space to move around, and I loved the work desk in there as I needed to get some work done on my laptop. The location was pretty good, I could see the hotel from Ginza area. The staff may struggle a little in English but they were very attentive and tried their best to understand and meet my needs. The breakfast may get a little crowded and there was a queue in the morning just to get into the buffet breakfast, so if you have a tight schedule to meet then you should wake up earlier.However, the only thing was that the wifi speed in the rooms were so slow, I couldn't load my emails and I had to resort to using my own mobile wifi unit to download some work emails.Nett, nice hotel to stay in with decent price.

Three of us stayed in one room in this hotel. Space was limited because we had the extra bed but I think without it a twin room would have been spacious enough. The room has everything you would need and the staff are very helpful. Rooms are clean. The hotel is about 7 mins walk to a subway station and is also near a train station although its a little tricky to find from the train station. There are numerous Italian restaurants in the area and there is also a family mart nearby. Overall good hotel, would definitely recommend and would stay here again.

We stayed here for our last night in Japan and it was great. The staff was helpful and the rooms are clean. There's a public bath on the top floor though we did not try it. The size of the room is normal for tokyo standards, a bit like the size of a budget hotel anywhere else in the world. It has great and fast wifi in the rooms and it is about 10mins walk to the nearest subway. I would definitely stay here again

I have stayed at this hotel many times over the past 6 years, its modern spotlessly clean and here is an onsen in the hotel so you can enjoy this Japanese tradition. The rooms are not large but they are functional, the only down side is there are no English TV channels, but hey you are not in Tokyo to watch TV.It is in a great location with nice cobblestone foot paths and italian style cafes and restaurants in the vicinity.The reception staff can speak english which is really helpful.

The room of this hotel, at its price, is almost incredible for Tokyo. Modern, spacious for a single room, well furnished, well-equipped (with a trouser press and bathtub), even with a designer flair about it, and the matress is very comfortable. If it fails to make my top transit hotel of Tokyo (at a reasonable price) it is the location. Shiodome is a good area but this hotel is on the flinge of Shiodome some 10 minutes' walk to a "useful" subway station (Shimbashi). Also it is unfair that they definitely do not allow you to check-in before 3pm (that;s what I was told) and will drive you out at 11am on check out. Your choice whether to have a good room and suffered the location and unreasonable rules. Staff practically do not speak English, though friendly.

This Hotel was one of the best Value Hotels in Tokyo, I must say. We stayed here for 5 nights and we paid a little over $700 USD. Room was clean and modern. The best part was, they had this Hot Bath (Onsen) at the top floor where you can enjoy traditional way of bathing in Japan. Hotel was very close to everything. You don't have to catch a taxi, you can walk to pretty much everything. I also liked that this hotel was next to Hamamachi station which was handy as if you land or depart from Haneda airport, you can take a direct train from there. I would go back there for sure.

This is a fantastic hotel, period. The location is great: in a quiet neighborhood and only at 10 minutes walking to Shimbashi train station. We booked a "small room" but in fact the room was quite wide with a big bed. We were lucky as we had a 8th floor room with a nice view to the back (garden and Tokyo skyline). Every day the room was completelly cleaned and all the refurbishments - towels, bathroom, coffee - were made carefully, which was really pleasant. All the details were carefully arranged for us. Bottomline: if I'll visit Tokyo again, I'll book it again.

This was a very nice hotel. The room and bathroom were clean and I would say the location is good because it is close to a metro station. However, bear in mind that you have to walk to the station and it's not under cover at all, so if you are going in the rainy season, you should be aware that you will need an umbrella.They have a public bath (onsen) and that is quite an experience -- very hot water!!! It's excellent after a long day of walking!Would I come back? Yes. But there are many other hotels to try first :)

"+" The hotel was perfect clean , with very helpful staff ( have one person who understands English little bit ) and tasty various European breakfast. Very quite area around but with some good restaurants. It' s really close (about 10-15 min walking) to Fish market ,Tokyo tower and to transport stations(5 min).Also there are a pleasant comfortable bed and pillow ))) "-" The same size of rooms for 2 and for 3 people, so the rooms for 3 people was so terrible small (we couldn't move). The hotel has a Japan bath ( open till 1am), but there not swimming pool ( you don't need bathing).

We stayed in the hotel for aweek and enjoyed nice location as well ascwell kept room. Room was quite compact but we knew that. We arroved to Hanada airport and there was a direct train from there to nearby Daimon Station. And next to Daimon was very handy Yamanote line JR Station. Shimbashi was also notvfar away. Hotel was modern and served reasonably good breakfast buffet with both western and oriental elements. Only minus was laundry, where some stains were left to trousers and no explanation was given - full charge. Anyone who has ever done any laundry, would have felt that material was linen and there fore bleach could have been used.

Mitsui Garden would be on the level of say a Hampton Inn in America of course the rooms are 1/4 the size in Tokyo but they function better. This is a step up from the business hotel chain Keio Presso. The beds are softer, room has a coffee maker, mini-fridge, hair dryer and in-room pants press. We had a double room which had enough room to store two bags, a desk with chair plus lounge chair and a small closet for about 5 pieces of clothing. For business the room had free, reliable in room wi -fi and adjustable air conditioning. We could get the room cool enough to sleep. It did not lock at 68F. The bathroom size was fine - it had a tub and shower with detachable head. Towels were thin. They had basket on counter with razor, toothbrush, etc in case you forgot. The hotel buffet did not look good and it was expensive so we skipped it. Elevators were fast - ours has three. They held our luggage on day of checkout. The location was easily walkable (about 8 min) to Hamatsucho or Shimbashi station (both on Yamanote JR line). Also Daimon subway station was right next to Hamatsucho. Shiodome is a new neighborhood so it doesn't have a lot of charm but the location was convenient and much quieter than Shibuya or Shinjuku for example. There are a lot of food options by the stations. Family Mart around the corner and a Pronto coffee a few blocks away as well. My two negatives were the pillows (like a thin rock) and second that I booked with otel.com. I got a good rate but I could not choose non-smoking and in Tokyo that is a major problem because almost all hotels are still half and half so we were on a smoking floor and the room smelled like an ashtray. Beware. Otherwise I would recommend this as a good business hotel option in Tokyo at the right price.

Booking this hotel was confusing. I thought I had scored a real bargain. Different booking sites showed very different prices for the "Mitsui Garden Hotel" in Tokyo. On the map both seemed to be in the same place, yet the prices varied wildely. So I was eager to book via the cheaper site, ready to enjoy some luxury and feel smug for having paid so little.Now that I'm actually in the hotel I understand. "Mitsui Garden" is a chain of hotels. They have one hotel in Shiodome, which is on the edge of the "Ginza" area. There's another Mitsu Garden hotel mere minutes away actually in Ginza. The latter is seriously expensive, the hotel in Shiodome is of average price.The Mitsu Garden of Shiodome is located in a neighbourhood with houses in European style. The pharse "little Italy" would overdo it, but there are several Italian restaurants, an Italian supermarket and some Italian themed shops here. The Mitsui Hotel doesn't have a restaurant of its own, but on the base floor (connected to the central lobby) is a buffet restaurant. And yes, it is Italian style. For those not so keen on a daily dose of cheese, pizza and olive oil there's a "Natural Lawson" supermarket next door. Very convenient!A walk to Ginza mainstreet takes about ten to fiveteen minutes. Mitsui Garden Shiodome is located between Shiodome stationa and Daimon station (the latter is also known as Hamamatsucho). Both require a 5 minute walk. That's not so bad every day, but when you have heavy luggage or in bad weather a hotel right on top of a station might be more convenient.While this Mitsui Garden isn't very luxurious, it doos look new, clean and stylish. The designers managed to set an elegant, modern theme which continues in the room. The room is compact, but there's enough space around the bed(s) for big suitcases. And then there's enough space for a desk and lazy chair as well. Some Tokyo hotels offer far less space for more money. Wifi and cable Internet are available for free. The connection speed is very low during the evening; in the morning and mid day speed is okay.The room is very well equiped, all basic things one expects at this price are there. Some noticeable things: the window in the room actually opens, which I found very pleasant. Every day roomservice brings two complimentary bottles of water to the room. There's a handy phone charger on the room, so one does not have to fiddle around with adapters.The cons: be aware that beds in Japan are generally hard and the beds in the Mitsui Hotel are even harder than average in Japan. The cushions seem to be filled with balls, seeds or something like that and are very uncomfortable. The air circilation in the bathroom is always on and can be pretty noisy. The room key is a paper (!) card and the staff urged me not to bend or fold it. The staff does speak English, or at least gives it a try. Do mind that this hotel is a little off centre, so the level of understaning English may leave something to be desired. So while this hotel wasn't a steal at this price, it did feel very Italian to me.

I agree with the majority of positive reviews here. I had a very nice room with a view of Tokyo Tower. However a warning for those people staying in the in-between seasons (spring and autumn). I was there during a warm spell in April, however the air-con is centrally controlled and set on heating. (The girl at the front desk read from a prepared script in English basically saying it's April therefore the heating is on regardless of the actual weather). So I was left with the choice of sweltering at night or opening the window (which meant it was very noisy with a construction site nearby). In other hotels in a similar price range you do have much more control over the temperature in your room.

We stayed here for 3 nights.Pros:*Good location, close to many train stations, a nice 25-min walk to Ginza/Imperial Palace, a 10-min walk to Tokyo Tower, right next to a convenience store*Spotlessly clean, not big but a systematic room with nice and simple decor, laundry facilities on the top floor in the public bath area*Friendly and efficient staffCons:*The all-you-can-eat dinner at the restaurant was pretty average.*This is essentially an upgraded Japanese business hotel. The pillow is quite low (just one) and the bed quite firm. I personally like it but some might find this difficult.Overall a great hotel in this price range. We had a great start to our 10-day holiday in Japan thanks to this hotel. Thank you!３日間泊まりました。良い点：*ロケーション　たくさんの駅に近く、銀座、皇居などへ２５分で散歩でき、東京タワーも１０分。コンビニもとなりです。*小さめですがシステマティックな部屋で、とても清潔でした。内装もシンプルかつモダンです。コインランドリーが最上階の浴場についていたので助かりました。*スタッフもフレンドリーでした残念な点：*バイキングの夕食をいただきましたが、残念ながらあまり美味しくありませんでした。

Great little hotel.Room is small and tight - but that is to be expected here in Tokyo ! 5 min walk to station Nice and quietClean public bath on 13 th floor that is VERY HOT!!!My hubby and two boys had the buffet for breakfast one day and got their money's worth ( kids were 6000 yen, hubby was 16000 yen) I prefer to pop around to the family mart or the lawson ( about 4 within 100 metres) and pick up breakfast and daily snacks for about 500 yen!!Superb pizza bar across the highway walkway called trico or triest or something like that... Anyway the pizza is the best I have ever eaten... It's on a corner near a car park Our room didn't have air con which was no problem cause it was cold, but would have been a major issue if it was hot ... Reception staff have limited English but were very helpful with maps and trains and directions Would recommend this hotel no probrem... He he !!

Reception don't seem to speak a great deal of English but it was OK at check-in. Receptionist was apologetic about the possible smell of smoke in a non-smoking room.Double room was a little small with the bed pushed against one wall so only one bedside table. However, it was quiet, nicely (if plainly) decorated and everything worked. All-singing and all-dancing toilet in the bathroom with a nice heated seat! Our room was on the east side and looked out toward Tokyo Tower. Room had a humidifier, trouser press, slippers, tea and coffee making facilities, Wifi and LAN. I had trouble connecting to the Wifi so pulled out the Travel Wifi adapter I'd brought with us and plugged it into the LAN creating our own Wifi which worked fine.Plenty of power outlets for charging appliances but only the two pin variety, I could not find a 3 pin in this room.To get to the hotel from Tokyo station by taxi cost us about 1300Yen and took between 10 and 15 minutes around 8:30pm on a Friday night.To get to Hamamatsucho JR station from the hotel, go out the front door, turn left, go slightly round the corner of the hotel, cross the road and go down the side road in front of you. It does a dog-leg to the left and then right and then its straight on to the station. We timed it and it took us 7 minutes from the hotel to the station platform.To get to the hotel from the station, take the North exit, cross the main road at the crossing and bear slightly left then take the narrow road to your right. It looks a little dark and lonely but its fine even late at night. The road does a dog-leg to the left, then right and the hotel is straight in front of you.There are some Italian restaurants (a little expensive from what we looked at) and a CocoCurry house on the street the hotel is on, go out the front door and bear right.There are more restaurants, pubs and bars on the streets near the station. Tokyo Tower is within walking distance (I think maybe 20-25 mins), we also walked back from the Tokyo station area through Ginza.There is a good view of the City from The World Trade Center Observatory, on the same road as the station.

As mentioned in the title, the hotel is very well located, close to Rail and metro station and is very well connected to the rest of the city and japan.the staff was very courteous, friendly and helpful. the staff paid full attention to ones needs and went out of the way to help and make oneself comfortable.we traveled in a group, one of us fell ill at the last moment and hence we had extra rooms, the staff went ahead and understood our issues, cancelled and modified the bookings on the day of arrival, thereby reducing the financial burden on us. the hotel was excellent with regards to cleanliness, room quality, comfort and services like, coffee, tv, air purifier, iron, free wifi, good mattresses etc

Hotel centrally located with lot of food joints around particularly a Japanese curry restaurant a few minutes down the road. Railway stations are also in close proximity, stations like hamamatsucho , daimon and Tokyo . At least one English speaking person is available at the front desk all the time. I d say the hotel is good value for money. Wi fi and lots of toiletries are thrown in as goodies. Overall a good hotel

Good location with easy access to the public transportation system in Tokyo. Less than 10 minute walk from Daimon or Hamamatsucho subway stations. Rooms were decently sized for Japan - very efficient use of space and clean. Free wifi although it was certainly spotty at times. Room included humidifier/air purifier (much needed as Tokyo is very dry) and safe (I've realized that not all Japan hotels have this). Staff was very helpful and courteous - not everyone speaks English though, but there is usually an individual or two at the front desk to assist. 24 hour Lawsons right next door for easy access to snacks and late night eats. Public bath house with a nice added bonus - again, very clean. Access to washer ($3) and dryer ($1 per 30 minutes); although dryer was not particularly strong and needed 90 minutes for clothes to dry. Breakfast was decent and good way to start the morning with a variety of Japanese/Western dishes. Depending on how much you are paying for it and if it's included in the deal, going to Lawsons or other nearby eateries might be cheaper. Very good value based on the other prices that we were seeing during our trip.

As titled, you get a nespresso machine, pant press, TV, free in-room wifi, air purifier with humidifier, safe, fridge, kettle ... etc. I don't think there is anything else missing from this room. The room is kept very clean and tidy, I found the mattress very good and not to mention the pillow, best ones for me so far with all Mitsui Garden hotels. They actually offer it in their brochure. Location of this hotel is slightly far from places like Ginza but still within walking distance. Many small restaurants near Daimon area and you can walk to a shrine nearby for a good stroll with the view of Tokyo Tower. Overall ranking is very good for me.ps. They have a large bath on the top floor for relaxation after a long day of shopping or work.

The rooms are modern and trendy. Clean and tidy. The location is great, within walking distance of Tokyo Tower, the fish market and the subway system. Great restaurant on site as well as several nice eateries a few blocks away. Comfortable bed. The staff are nice and helpful. The store Lawson's is about a 10 minute walk from Hotel.

Good points:near the Hamamatsucho station of the Tokyo monorail.near the Tsuikji fish market.offers a public bath in its premise.cleanliness not an issue.buckwheat pillows - nice!nice breakfast.friendly staff.not so good:small toilet, washing up areaan advice:return to the hotel via the Daimon or Hamamatsucho station. We return via the Shimbashi stations on some occasions and found ourselves hopelessly lost, in cold winter nights!

Nice Hotel nice and friendly staffI enjoyed staying in this Hoteleven the room was small but it was great ! And the location was so so perfect near the station and near the tokyo tower and near of alot Supermarkets and Resturants.Thanks Mitsui Garden Sure I'll visit you again

Stayed here 7 days for business. This is a very nice hotel, it located between JR Hamamatsucho sta and Shiodome metro sta, by around 10 mins walk. Within 2 min walk there is a Familymart.The lobby is well decorated. Staffs are nice and good in English. The room was very clean and well stocked. The bed was comfortable, but the pillow is as hard as the stone.The most amazing part is the traditional large public bath on the top floor of the hotel, which all the tourist may want to experience it.

We didn't actually stay here, but wished we had been after the experience we had with the staff. Having got myself completely confused, I thought we were staying at this hotel, so through torrential rain we arrived dripping on their lovely marble floor, feeling somewhat grumpy and worse for wear (we missed the memo about taking an umbrella when visiting Tokyo). As we battled with bags and coats, one of the ladies from the desk came over with a big sympathetic smile and a towel for each of us. She cheerfully took our names and, upon establishing we'd got the wrong place, and me realising my mistake, grabbed a map and helped us find where we were supposed to be. This was great in itself and we already felt better about the whole thing, but as we were leaving, the lady ran over to us with two umbrellas. I was so grateful I could have cried and it went a very very long way to cementing our positive view of the Japanese people, and I just wish we could have done something more to say thank you!

Easy access hotel, good value for money, very clean rooms; it was a great stay. I would highly recommend this hotel. Communicating with staff was difficult, as level of foreign languages spoken is low - but it didn't stop the staff from being overly helpful and kind.Rooms were nice and clean. Bathroom ceiling was strangely lower than the rest of the room - only a few cms above my partner's head. The rooms felt hot, and the elevator was strangely 5 degrees hotter - quite uncomfortable when trying to shield yourself from a 30+ degree day. But overall, really liked the hotel, would definitely return!

When I checked into the hotel front office staff was very welcoming.I went into the room to realise that this hotel starts and ends at the entrance. Rooms are very small with many amenities being stuffed into this room.The back side rooms have no view with window opening into big building.Breakfast is a big put off and I advise you buy your own breakfast and have it in the room. I later saw many people doing the same.There is a convenient store in the next building (Lawson)- you an buy cut fruits, juice, coffee and breakfast is done.I must admit that hotel staff is helpful and they refunded me my breakfast money because I decided not to eat due to limited options for me.Overall if you need to stay for a day or two- it is not a bad deal.

Mitsui Garden Hotel is conveniently located between 2 main JR stations, Shimbashi and Hamamatsucho, Metro lines Oedo, Asakusa, Mita lines and also the Tokyo Monorail (to Haneda Airport). It is easy access to anywhere you need to go in Tokyo as well as to Haneda Airport. It is a quiet business area with many restaurants and bars but without the rowdiness of Shinjuku. Since its mainly a business area, weekends are very quiet and nice. Zozoji temple with Tokyo tower as its backdrop is just a short walk away as well!The hotel is modern, clean, well maintained. Our double room was very spacious for a Japanese hotel, the room was fully equipped with the basics. as well as Wifi.A perk was the Japanese style bath upstairs- small but it did the job. I have a soft spot for Hamamatsucho, so it was great to find yet another great hotel in this area. It is now my new favorite. Having stayed at MyStays and Chisun in Hamamatsucho, Mitsui Garden is certainly the winner among the three. The main reason would probably be that it feels more like a real hotel and less like a business hotel (as is the case for MyStays and Chisun). My only complaint would be the room didnt't have very bright lights, so at night, it can feel pretty dark.

Although the room was a bit small, but its very clean, their staffs don't speak very good English, but still very friendly. There's plenty of restaurants within 10-15 mins walk, all very good. Also there are 2 underground and a familymart within 10mins walk.It offers a large public bath on the top floor of this hotel, which you may want to experience. ;-)

We have been in this hotel for 3 days, before we have stayed close to Ginza area. Anyhow, we strongly recommend this hotel. It has everything needed for a good time in Tokyo. Nice big rooms for a good price, close to points of interest as well to tube station. Quiet, comfortable, wifi.. If you are young couple staying in Tokyo for several days, right place to stay. The staff is great as well, good English.

Stayed here quite a few times on business. A bit of a walk to closest train station. Quite part of town. Other than the public bath, there isn't much in the way of common areas and no gym. Room itself has everything one would need. Comfortable.

Stayed in this hotel as it was the only one we could find at busy Christmas time which had bedrooms with 3 beds to cater for our family. We found it was easier to access this hotel from the JR shimbashi station (10 minutes walk) as most trains leave from there. Whilst the shiodome station is a little closer it is not a major station and you will need to change trains straight away at the next station most times. Upon arrival go to a JR station and buy a Suica card which will give you access to all the transport in Tokyo. Be wary as some train passes only allow access to some train lines. We found that when we had luggage or tired at the end of the day exploring Tokyo it was easier to get a taxi back to the hotel approx 710y. Hotel is in a quieter neighbourhood away from the hassle and bustle. Although there were a number of convenience stores close by for snacks.

Well placed, business hotel. Good sized room, very good breakfast, extremely helpful staff at the reception, all at a reasonable price.I spent 7 nights on a business trip to Japan an have nothing but good comments about it.Would not hesitate to recommend it.

The hotel is close to jr Hamamatsuchiu station/ subway Daimon sta, just less than 10minutes walk with luggages. It is also close to Shiodome station where you can take train to Odaiba, less than 10minutes walk. Reception staffs are very nice, and they can speak English. The best part of the hotel is the public spa bath on the top floor opened till midnight. Japanese style, letting you relax after a busy day in Tokyo. Beds are very comfortable.Three bed room is same size as two beds room, so it is too squeeze. And though it is a non smoking room, it often have a smoking smell at night. Wifi link was broken one night, the staff tried their best to solve it (though not working), the good is they also have wired link which is also free.

Nice room in a quiet neighborhood. Close to a subway station. Interior is quite good and the internet is free, although the connection gets slow when other guests are using it all at the same time.Staffs are nice and helpful.
small rooms although normal for Japan, lovely architecture and very near to Shiodome/Shimbashi St. You can walk to Ginza, Tsukiji etc.

Traveling during freezing winter time to Tokyo, I feel like having the hot bath everyday. For those bath lovers,like me, cannot stand the usual bath tub in rooms, this is the hotel to come; there is a big bath on the top floor for you to stretch your legs in a big bath to relax! It also has a self-service laundry machine in the public bath area for you to wash your clothes if necessary. I have stayed here for 5 nights during January. Though it is a bit far from station (approx 8-10 min), the hotel is still nicely served by convenience stores and a nice restaurant on the ground level. It is within walking distance from Shinbashi or Hamamatsucho station. The room is slightly bigger than its sister branch in Ginza.

The only thing I did not like about this hotel was it took the front desk more than 30 minutes for them to check us in considering it was already past 10pm and we came from a four hour flight and an additional hour drive from Narita.Hotel lobby though could use a few more seats.Aside from that the room was nice, spacious and clean. However there were no english channels showing on the TV.Toilet and bath was a bit small but clean and well lit.Buffet breakfast was great! Choices were Japanese, Italian and a bit of continental.Overall we enjoyed our stay in this hotel.

Really nothing interesting in the nearby area but the room was surely spacious and equipped with all the things you need both business or leisure. After one long day, you can use the large "Ofuro" - bath on the top floor. Italian restaurant on the ground floor offers decent food at a reasonable price but I recommend to walk near daimon station and visit the small restaurant instead. Walking distant through shiodome to ginza which is good but slightly far. If you take a taxi, taxi driver will mistaken easily to the Mitsui garden premier in ginza, so you should tell him it's next to the JRA building. Walking distance from daimon which is great if you are coming by monorail. Nearby tsukiji fish market also.

I stayed in this hotel in early August. I went to Japan more than 10 times, and this is my worst and horrible hotel experience in Japan.After 2 nights stay, I found my face and neck was bitten by the bugs seriously. Obviously, their bed is not clean and which resulted in my illness. I told the clerk what happened to me right away. The sickness made me very very uncomfortable and couldn't sleep whole night. The clerk gave me some medicine bit it didn't work. She only said she's sorry. I even had to find the doctor by myself. They broke my vacation.I communicated with the hotel several times. What they did was keeping saying sorry, but they refused to admit it's their fault. They said " It never happen before. We don't know why it happen to you." It's too ridicious. I'll never stay in this hotel again.

The rooms are beautiful and modern, and the bathrooms impeccably new and spacious. It was a great room to come home to and made the hectic and travel of the day melt away with its aesthetic, fantastic designs. Loved it and wish every hotel I stayed at was like this one!!

I usually stayed in Mitsui Garden Ginza, its sister hotel. But I got a very good deal including breakfast, so I decided to try. It turned out satisfying. Nothing grand about the breakfast buffet, but it was certainly more than enough. Room was spacious compare to Japan standard. Close to Tsukiji, the fish market and Ginza. Me and my sister enjoyed a camembert cheese pizza at the close by Italian restaurant. Highly recommended!

I was really pleased with this hotel. The rooms were excellent, the free public bath a wonderful bonus and the service was polite with staff who spoke good English. I was particlarly pleased with the hotel's location. A ten or fifteen minute walk into Ginza, there really is no need to take the subway or hire a taxi. The JR station is a 5 min walk away (with luggage), ideal if you are on a budget and have the JR rail pass. We used this all the time in Tokyo and found that we never needed the metro. The district around the Hamamatsucho Station is very well served with excellent retaurants and the fish market is within walking distance if you fancy checking it out before breakfast.The hotel restaurant is expensive and so too is the breakfast. at around 20€. Still, we tried it once and thoroughly enjoyed the range of tastes. Afterwards we settled for nearby cafés in the morning. I would heartily recommend this hotel to any visitor to Tokyo.

The Garden Hotel was about 5 mins walking distance from the nearest station but we used mostly taxi because it was heavily raining and our 10 month-old baby was with us. Hotel is very new and fancy, and our room looked very clean with new electronic devices. It was very small room, though. I guess we all have to expect that in Japan. For those who would like to experience Japanese public bath, there is one at the top floor. Of course men and women are separated. Breakfast buffet was satisfactory.
